(11. 1) Mr.               ZEMSKOV                   (Union          of Soviet          Socialist         Republics)             (Translation              from       the Russian):
         Mr.        President,               delegates,                we are assembled                     here to discuss                 the subject           of Unesco’s            budget-
ary deficit            resulting             from          the devaluation                   of the US dollar              and inflation.                   The delegation                of the
USSR takes               a serious              view both of the financial                             position       of the Organization                    and of the causes                 res-
ponsible          for it.           That is only natural.                             The Soviet           Union        - a country            with the most advanced                       type
of social           and State structure,                           unaffected             by any of the financial                    and currency               crises        and other         UP-
heavals         to which             capitalist              society          is subject           - takes        a completely              impartial          view of the situation
which       has now arisen                      in Unesco,                for which             neither       it nor the other                socialist        countries           are in any
way responsible.
(11. 2) The Soviet                      Union,            as an active               member            of Unesco           and a substantial                 contributor            to Unesco’s
budget,          cannot          remain            indifferent              to its fate or to the policy                       it pursues.               It is for this           reason       that
we consider                it important,                   at this stage,                to make a realistic                  assessment                of the situation              on account
of which           it was decided                    to convene               this extraordinary                   session.
(11. 3) The USSR delegation                                     considers             that it would             be incorrect              to represent             Unesco’s          present
difficulties,              as several                speakers             at the 93rd session                     of the Executive                Board        did, as a “crisis”                 or
a “catastrophe”.                        It must not be forgotten                              that Unesco’s            budget         for 1973-1974                already        exceeds        the
budget        for the previous                       biennium             by an enormous                   sum - 30 million                   dollars.          It is common              know-
ledge,        also,         that a considerable                         number            of Member              States      have not yet paid a11 or part of their
contributions                 for the previous                       biennium            - 1971-l        972 - and that some                        of them           have not paid for
 several        years           past.          In these conditions,                         ladies      and gentlemen,                  it scarcely           seems        right       to propose
meeting           the deficit              by calling             for supplementary                      contributions             from        Member           States.          As you know,
when the Soviet                    delegation                raises        the problem               in Unesco           of the rational              and strictly           economical
use of the Organization’s                                resources,                 attempts          are sometimes                made to misrepresent                         the very        basis
 of our position,                  to sow doubts                     about the Soviet                 Union’s        attitude        to Unesco’s             programme               and about
 our readiness                  to help the developing                            countries           in their       praiseworthy               struggle          to set up an indepen-
 dent economy,                   eradicate              illiteracy,              and achieve             progress.
 (11. 4) We would                     like to stress                   once again that the Soviet                         Union        - the first          workers’           State,      founded
 by the great               Lenin          - has from                the very          first      days of its existence,                        not by words                 but by deeds,
 afforded           disinterested                  assistance               to the peoples                 of the developing                      countries            in their          struggle
 against        colonialism                 and for the right                      to be their           own masters.                    The Soviet            Union        did not desist
                                                                                                     146


                                                                                                                                                                                                3XC/2
  from      its self-sacrificing                      efforts           even in the most difficult                            periods          of its history,                as the peoples
  of Asia,         Africa       and L,atin America                           are well aware.                       At the XXIVth                     Congress             of the CPSU,                   the
  Secretary-General                    of the Central                     Committee               of the CPSU,                  L. 1. Brezhnev,                  emphasized              particular-
  ly that “despite              a11 difficulties                    and even in some instances                                 defeats,           social       changes           of various           kinds
  are taking           place     throughout                 large         areas        of the world.                  The workers                 are winning              important           victories
  in the struggle             for their             rights,           for true freedom                       and for the defence                           of human               dignity.            The
  patriots        of countries             still        groaning            under        the colonial               yoke are continuing                       their      courageous              fight
  for liberation.               Our country                   “, L. 1. Brezhnev                      stressed,              “is doing everything                      to support           this just
  fight.     The USSR’s              political             and economic                  co-operation                 with       the       countries            which           have      won        their
  liberation          has developed                  still       further         in recent            years.           Our trade              with them is expanding.                           With
  our co-operation,                   dozens            of industrial               and agricultural                    firms          have been set up in many Asian                                  and
  African         States.        We also contribute                           towards           the training               of qualified            personnel            for these countries.
  And a11 this is done in the interests                                       of both sides”.
  (11. 5) The Soviet                 Union’s              efforts         in this field             have now assumed                         particularly             large        proportions.
  It was the Soviet               Union          that proposed                   placing          on the agenda                 of the XXVIIIth                 session           of the United
 Nations          General        Assembly                  the important                 and urgent              question            of “Reduction               of the military               budgets
  of States         Permanent             Members                   of the Security                Council           by 10 per cent and utilization                                of part of the
  funds thus saved to provide                               assistance              to developing                 countries”.                 Our proposa1               was formulated                  in
  clear      and precise            terms            by a member                   of the Politburo                   of the General                      Committee                 of the Party,
 USSR Foreign                Minister             A. A. Gromyko,                       in his address                  to the United               Nations          General           Assembly.
  The Soviet           Union has for many years                                  past been pressing                        for the rationalization                       of Unesco’s              ex-
 penditure,             SO that the bulk of its resources                                     may be spent on developing                                 the Organization’s                    pro-
  gramme,            instead        of being swallowed                          up by the bureaucratie                            machinery.                It is no secret               that over
 60 percent            of Unesco’s              budget            goes to pay for the staff and other                                       administrative                expenses,            whilst
 less than 40 per cent is spent on assistance                                                  to the developing                      countries.             It is understandable                      that
 a11 Member              States would                 like to see this position                           changed.
  (11. 6) Now,             ladies        and gentlemen,                       let us turn our attention                            to practical             matters.              This session
 has been presented                     with the figure                     of $12,600,000,                     representing                 the deficit          of the Organization,
 which        it is proposed              to caver              by supplementary                       contributions                  from       Member           States. We are aware
 of course,            that this figure                   was originally                 even higher,                  SO that we are                     bound         to admit            that        the
 Unesco          Secretariat            and the Executive                         Board         have already                 made some effort                     to find means               within
 the Organization                 for overcoming                        the financial              difficulties.                But at the same time,                           we must say
 ihat our delegation                   is convinced                   that neither              the Secretariat                   nor the Executive                    Board         has by any
 means          exhausted          the possibilities                      of effecting             interna1          economies              to reduce          the budget deficit               further.
(11. 7) Before               analysing             these unexploited                       possibilities              for effecting               economies             in specific           sectors
of the Organization’s                      activities,                  we would             like       to suggest               certain          general         ways          in which          the
General           Conference            might obtain                  supplementary                  interna1          resources.              This could be done, we consider,
by “freezing”               a number              of vacant              posts in the Unesco                       Secretariat;                eliminating             or at least           redu-
cing the reclassification                          of posts;               cutting        down the number                       of conferences,                  meetings            and missions;
reducing           the number             of publications                     and documents;                     greatly          reducing           the number               of consultants
employed            by Unesco;              stopping               the construction                   of new buildings                    for Unesco;               reorganizing              cer,tain
units      of the Organization;                          and cutting             down the number                      of ineffectual,                 overlapping               programmes.
1 would like to ask delegates                                to note particularly                       that our proposals                       relate      mainly         to cuts in adminis-
trative         and various            other         unproductive                  expenses             of the Organization,                       which        should          not impair           the
quality         of Unesco’s           programmes                       or affect          them quantitatively                        to any extent.
(11. 8) Following                  up the views                   we expressed                 at the 93rd session                        of the Executive                  Board,         we would
like today to make a number                                  of practical               suggestions               which,          if carried           out, would,               in our view,
not only achieve                considerable                    financial           savings          but also improve                      the programme.                       1 would      like to
emphasize             that it is a case of improvements                                         as well as of financial                         savings.            In the opinion              of the
Soviet        delegation,           it is essential                    to strike          a balance,              in the interests                  of the Organization,                    between
the regular             budget       and extra-budgetary                             resources.                There          has in the past few years                            been a dan-
gerous          tendency          to transform                     various          sectors          of Unesco              into executors                of projects.                Take,        for
instance,           the development                      programmes                   of the UN and the International                                  Bank for Reconstruction
and Development.                      According                 to the 197 3 -1974 programme,                                    the Education                Sector         is to administer
extra-budgetary                 funds of UNDP,                         amounting            to more            than twice               as much as its own budget.                              1 shall
give you the figures                     - $57,900,000                      and $27,200,000                      respectively.                   At the same time,                     considerable
sums from              Unesco’s           budget            are used to caver                      part      of the administrative                        expenses             involved        in such

  13. 1           Mr.       LOMBE              (Zambia):
                  Thank         you,       Mr.         President.                May       1 first        of     a11 congratulate                     you     on your          appoint-
  ment       as      President            of this          extraordinary                  session          of     the     General              Conference?                  1 would          al-
  SO like         to compliment                     you     on the       way       in which            you       have       created             an environment                   in which
 we     are       able      to meet           and       exchange            ideas        on the         problem             facing          the      Organization.                   1 wish
  to assure             you     that      we       shall       do our        best      to   respect             the     Conference                  time-table.
   13. 2            Today,         Wednesday,                   24October             1973,         is    Zambia’s               Independence                  Day.          The        Party,
   the    Government                  and      the      people         of the        Republic            are      holding           celebrations                a11 over            the   coun-
   try    in    honour           of the       day       nine       years       ago      when         we     were         freed         from         colonial         rule.
                                                                                              149


13. 3        One      reflection              among        others         which      this      day always              evokes        in our        minds       is that
we did not become                     independent             in order           to be dependent.                    We have          no doubt           that    those
who have          known          colonialism             and those            who     are      still    colonized            Will     appreciate            what      we
mean      and Will          understand               our    feelings.
13. 4           We would              like      to believe           that    our     presence           here        today      is not only           a continuation
and demonstration                     of our        national          freedom         and independence,                      but a clear            indication           of
our    wish      to see how best                   we cari share              the fruits           of our        freedom          with      those        who,      for     no
fault    of their         own,      are still         struggling            to free       themselves               from       the yoke          of colonialism
and the other              isms        that      go with       it.
13. 5        In applying              ourselves            to this        cause,       we are          constantly            hopeful         that     our     national
philosophy           of humanism                  Will    appeal         to the hearts               of men        and inspire             them       to become
harbingers            of peace,           justice        and honour             for    a11 and for            the future           generations              of this
small      world.
13. 6         This      is a high            ideal     which         we have         set for         ourselves.              But we believe                that     it is
an ideal        for    a11 those            who believe              in the universality                 of mankind.                Elements            ofhumanism
being     universal,              they       influence         much         of what        Unesco         stands          for.      It is this         thought        that
partly      contributes              to our        belief      that      the founding             and existence                of Unesco           were       not a mere
happy      accident            but a meaningful                  manifestation                of service            to mankind.
13. 7        At this          point,        therefore,            the question             is whether              we are        ready        to do just         that - to
render        service          to Man.             The     task       of serving          involves          finding         ways       and means             of solving
some      basic        and major               problems            that     underlie         the absence               of conditions             in which         peace
and fraternity               cari exist.             This     is a challenge                which       is both          material          and spiritual,                a
challenge          that      must        be continuously                 faced      and honestly               tackled         without         reservations              or
inhibitions.             We cannot               run    away        from       the bitter          fact    that       whatever          we leave           undone         or
whatever          we destroy               is to the disadvantage                      of nobody           but ourselves                in Unesco            and       the
world      at large.
13. 8         In this        respect,            the developed               countries          and the developing                     countries           must       en-
gage     together           in the tedious               and sometimes                  frustrating             job     not only        of “BUILDING                  DE-
FENCES           IN THE            MINDS           OF     MEN”          but of pulling             down       the rotten           ones       as well.
 13. 9        The     job       does      not end there                because        in some           cases         the minds           themselves             are
rotten      and must             be replaced              by innocent             minds        worthyof             protection           from       the evil        in-
fluences         of injustice,               inequality,            hatred,         discrimination,                   racialism           and conflict.
 13. 10       In order           to stand          up to this           collective         responsibility                in Unesco,             we cari see no
other      source         of courage              than     total       and genuine             dedication            to the service               of mankind.
 13. 11        This      is an essential                element           in the cultivation                and maintenance                     of high       morale
during       the depressing                   hours       of our        task.

                                                                                                                                                              3XCl2
13 12       Just     now we are            called         upon       to face        one of those            depressing            moments           in the life
of the Organization.                   We a11 know               that    the financial             morale       of Unesco          has been threatened
and in fact        shaken        by events           that     lie     outside         the Organization               itself.
13. 13      Morale        would        decline        still      further        if Member             States       were       to remain          indifferent
and disinterested.                 At this       moment             of crisis          - and it is a crisis                - Member            States      have
demonstrated            one thing,          that      high       morale         is not a result              of regimented              discipline          or
control      but of a truc           acceptance              of challenge              by individual            Member           States.
13. 14      We take        it,    therefore,             that      acceptance             of this      challenge         shows        how      concerned
we are      with     the need         to combat             the effects            of inflation         and devaluation               of the currency
of accounting.

of the Organization                - to take          a stand.

I venture       to say, violated             the authority               of the previous                General         Conference            decisions          or
resolutions.
 13. 18      This     evasion        of our        commitments                  when        it suits      us seems           to be developing               into
an accepted           method        of procedure                in dealing           with       issues     which       we know          are     of major         im-
portance        to some         Member           States.            As a result,               the idea       of the General             Conference            being
the supreme            organ       of the Organization                     is becoming              nothing       but a mockery.
 13. 19      In practice,           Member            States         may      approve            a policy      decision         one day and two days
later     do a11 they         cari to undermine                   that     same         decision.

 meetings        and     conferences             like       this     one,     if only to pretend               to make          some       temporary           ac-
 ceptable       sense      out of them             in order           to keep         the Organization                going.
  13. 21     We seem           to have        lost      the original             sense         of direction         and purpose             and instead           we

 body.

        La troisième            séance      plénière          est ouverte.
 1. 2 Douze          orateurs       sont    inscrits         pour      aujourd’hui             et dix-huit         autres       pour    demain.       Il y
a donc        peu de chances            pour    que nous           puissions          terminer           demain.         Je vous       serais      néan-
moins        reconnaissant           de reduire         le plus         possible          la durée        de vos      interventions            et de ne
pas    sortir       du sujet.      J’essaierai           pour       ma part          de faciliter          au maximum              vos    debats     sur
cette      question       assez     technique.

légation        de la Suisse.
 2. 1 M.        HUMMEL           (Suisse)       :
        Monsieur          le Président,           il y a à peine             un an,         nous     étions      réunis       dans     cette    meme
 salle     afin    de debattre         du budget        de notre           Organisation             pour     l’exercice          biennal       1973- 1974.
II y eut,        vous    le savez,        désaccord,             voire      division          profonde.         Un nombre            considérable
d’Etats        membres,          représentant            une partie            très      importante          des     contributions,            n’a   pas
voté     le plafond         budgétaire        proposé,            estimant          qu’il     était    possible        de faire       des    économies
 - je dis bien,          des    economies           - sans        toucher          à la substance            du programme.
 2. 2 Aujourd’hui,              nous     sommes          à nouveau            reunis         pour    voter      un budget         supplémentaire,
 pour     les    raisons       que vous       connaissez.              On aurait            pu supposer           que nous         serions      encore
 plus    profondément            divisés.        Mais      j’ai     le sentiment,               Monsieur          le Président           - et cela      mal-
 gre   les     deux    interventions           des délégations                que nous          avons       entendues          ce matin       - que     le
 contraire         est vrai      et je m’en         réjouis.          J’ai    le sentiment             que les       difficultés        que traverse
 l’Organisation            nous    ont rapprochés               dans       un réflexe           de solidarité.

 2. 3 La question                qui nous         est    soumise           maintenant             a été préalablement                  étudiée,        nous      ve-
nons       d’en     étre     informés          en détail          ce matin,         par     le Conseil          exécutif.         Nous      avons       suivi    très
attentivement              les    travaux         du Conseil            exécutif         sur     ce point.         Nous       avons     pu nous         rendre
 compte        du soin         et de la conscience                   profonde          de ses       responsabilités               avec     lesquels        le Con-
 seil    executif        a examiné           la question.              Nous       avons       pu faire        une autre          constatation          - et ceci
nous       a rendu       particulièrement                  heureux            : tous     les    membres            du Conseil          exécutif       ont abordé
le problème             difficile        qui nous        preoccupe               dans     un esprit         remarquablement                   constructif.
De part         et d’autre,           on a pu sentir              la volonté           d’arriver         à une solution              acceptable           sinon
par     tous     les    membres            du Conseil,              au moins           par     une très        large       majorité.          Nous      avons
 également           pu nous         rendre        compte         des     efforts        que le Directeur                genéral       a déployes            afin
d’aider        le Conseil           exécutif        à parvenir            à un résultat             positif       et nous       tenons       à l’en     remer-
 cier     chaleureusement.                   Nous      avons         pu constater             tout    à l’heure         combien         ces      concessions
lui   ont été difficiles               à accepter.            Je vous            avouerai        toutefois         que nous        ne partageons               pas
 son pessimisme                 au sujet         des    effets        de ces       économies           nécessaires.

Conseil         exécutif        a approuvé            à la quasi           unanimité           le projet         de résolution            qu’ilnous        soumet.

lier,      l’expression             de notre        confiance            dans      les    travaux        du Conseil            exécutif        ; l’expression
 aussi      de notre         satisfaction           et de notre            gratitude          à l’égard         de l’esprit         de conciliation              qui
 a inspiré         les    membres           du Conseil              exécutif        et le Directeur               général,         Nous espérons               que

(il faut      faire     des économies)                  - et,       si possible,            sans     aucun        changement            et à l’unanimité              -
le projet         de résolution             qui nous         est proposé.
 2. 6 Monsieur               le Président,             la Suisse,              consciente          des problèmes               de trésorerie             qui vont

4. 2 Il y a un peu plus                  d’un mois,           dès l’ouverture              - au sein du Conseil                 exécutif        réuni     en sa 93e
session       - du long débat             consacré          à la situation         financière          de l’Organisation,                   mon gouverne-
ment,       par la voix           de son représentant                 au Conseil           exécutif,         avait     d’entrée         de jeu,      exprimé
une attitude           claire      et sans équivoque.                 Nous avions           d’abord       déclaré,           en effet,        que la necessite
d’avoir       recours            à une     réunion         extraordinaire               de la Conference                  générale          nous      paraissait
l’évidence           méme,          puisque        le Conseil            ne pouvait,           dans     le cadre           de ses attributions                   nor-

que la procedure                   de résorption             du déficit        budgétaire,             et notamment                 de la part          due à la
dévaluation            proprement             dite,      devrait,          autant      que possible,                ne pas       @tre de nature               à en-
trainer       une remise               en cause         du programme                 approuvé          par      la Conférence                générale          à sa
dix-septième                session.        Aussi,         tout     en approuvant              les   mesures             d’économies              dejà     réali-
 sees     par    le Directeur               général         et qui visaient             d’ailleurs          essentiellement                  à reduire          les

 additionnels,              afin    de couvrir           un montant           qui     représentait             encore         près      de 16 millions               de
 dollars.
4. 3 En l’occurrence,                       nous      n’entendions            nullement            donner         l’impression              que notre           souci
de rigueur            en matière            budgétaire,             constamment               exprime          dans       cette      assemblée             àl’heure
des     choix       financiers,           nous      avait       quittés.       Notre        preoccupation               devant        ce grave          problème
 était    d’une       toute       autre     nature        : il nous        paraissait           en effet       à la fois         injuste       et dangereux
de remettre               en discussion,              pour      des      raisons        sérieuses          mais        fortuites,          le support           finan-
 cier     destine         à assurer          - deux        ans durant          - la mise           en oeuvre            d’activites           déjà    conçues          et
 approuvées.               A cet égard,           nous       avons        eté heureux            de constater,              à l’issue          du débat         du
 Conseil,         que notre           manière          de voir        traduisait,           à l’evidence,              un sentiment              général.

6. 1         Mr.        CHATTERJEE                    (India):
             Mr.       President           and      distinguished              delegates,             this     extraordinary                session        of the
General        Conference            has assembled                  to consider           the financial           crisis       facing      Unesco           which,
as we are          well     aware,         is largely           due to economic                 and monetary              factors       over      which        the
Organization            has little         control.           TO some          extent,         the financial          difficulties           of the Organi-
zation      are     connected           with     the     problems           of its      growth        and show          that    it has had to pay                the
price      of endeavour            and advance.                  We are       a11 committed               to the achievement                   of the      three
main      objectives          of Unesco:           firstly,         the contribution               of Unesco          to economic               and     social
development;              secondly,            the contribution               of Unesco           to peace,         and thirdly           the contribution
of Unesco          to ethical        and moral              ends.       Looking          to the future          of Unesco           and its        expandimg
raie    in the evolution               of a world           community,             it is the duty           of the Member                States       to rally
to the support            of the Organization                    in this      hour      of trial,        and to ensure             that    Unesco          is
strengthened            and reinvigerated                   to function          effectively          in the vast          and significant             fields       of
its   action.
 6. 2         Mr.     President,            the budget           for 1973-1974             approved         by the 1972 General                   Conference
amounted          to $119,        954, 000.            The      additional         costs      arising       from       inflation        as on 1. 9. 1973
are    estimated          to be of the order                  of $7, 847, 900.                The     Director-General’s                   proposa1           that
                                                                               160


                                                                                                                                                                  3XCl3
these    additional            costs      may      be met           by economies               in expenditure              and by utilizationof                   the
appropriation             reserve          has been           approved            by the Executive                Board.           This      leaves        the major
deficit     resulting           from      the devaluation                 of the US dollar                 to be dealt         with.         This      deficit      is
estimated          to be of the order                 of $15,          852, 100.          After        taking      credit       for     further        economies
to the extent           of $1, 600, 000 and contributions                                by two new            Member            States       estimated          to be
about     $1, 600, 000,              we have         still      to find       resources            to the extent           of $12,         652, 100.          We want
to express           our     appreciation             of the work              done     by the Director-General                          in restructuring
the budget           SO as to secure               substantial             economies             without       cutting       into      the main           elements
of the programme.                      The position              now reached              is that         the   Member           States       are      beingaskeci
to agree        to the adoption               of supplementary                     estimates           to caver        this     very       substantial           deficit
of $12,      652 million.
 6. 3        Mr.       President,            1 would         like      to reiterate           two important               considerations                 bearing       on
the phenomenal                increase          in the budget               deficit,       which         were     emphasized               at the last          meeting
of the Executive                Board       by the Indian                member,           Mr.        G. Parthasarathi.                     The     first      is that
the budget           deficit      has arisen           because            of domestic             inflation       in the developed                  countries         and
the instability             and periodic            fluctuation             of some         international            currencies,                and particularly
the devaluation               of the US dollar                vis-à-vis            the currencies               of certain          other       developedcoun-
tries.       Speaking           as a representative                      of a developing                country,        1 must        say      that    it seems          to
me inequitable               that     the burden            of a part          of the deficit             caused      by currency               instabilityin          the
 developed          countries           should      be passed              on by them            to the developing                countries            as a result
 of increasing            the latter’s           proportionate                contribution              towards       the general              budget        of Unesco.
 The    developing            countries,           by and large,                 are    not responsible               for     the crisis           and they        are
least    able       to bear        the extra         burden           of an increased                contribution.
 6.4         In order          to prevent           such       an eventuality              in the future,             the Consultative                   Committee
 on Administration                  Questions           had made             the following              proposals:
             (1)      The      use     of Special          Drawing            Rights       on a “unit          of account”            related         to the par
 value    of the dollar              to gold       as the basis              of assessment.
              (2)     Use      of a currency               other        than     the dollar           for    budgeting         and the assessment                     of
 contributions.
              (3)     Assessment               of Member               States,        partly       in dollars         and partly            in the currency
 of the host          country,          the latter          at a rate          fïxed     at the time           the budget           is voted.
 6. 5         Mr.      President,             we feel         that      the General             Conference           should         give      serious         consid-
 eration       to these         proposals.             The        fluctuations           in the rate           of exchange             of important              cur-
 rencies        may      continue         for     a considerable                 time,       and Unesco             may      be hamstrung                 with    un-
 expected         and heavy            deficits       at any time              due to manipulations                    in the rates              of exchange.
  This   pinpoints           the need         to work          out fundamental                  and long-term               solutions.
                                                                                     161


 3XCl3
 6. 6          1 would         suggest         that,      in view        of the very          heavy         deficit     caused        by the present              cur-
rency        crisis,         this     General          Conference            make      an appeal             to a11 Member             States      whose         cur-
rencies          have       appreciated            in terms          of the dollar           to pay their             contributions           for    thecurrent
biennium             in their        own currencies                at the rates          pledged           by them         before      devaluation.              Such
 action       on their         part      Will    be a valuable             palliative         and help          the Director-General                     to balance
the budget             for    the current            biennium.
 6. 7          Mr.       President,             1 now corne           to the second             important            consideration            which        1 have in
mind.          We know            that      steps      have     been      taken      to effect        substantial            economies          in    the     pro-
 gramme           to meet          the joint         challenge          of inflation         and devaluation.                     We     are     in    full     sym-
pathy       with       the view         that     such      economies            should       not impinge              on the operative             efficiency
 of the different               programmes,                 particularly            those      designed           to assist        the developing             Mem-
ber      States.           We would           suggest        that    the search           should         be continued            for    further       sizeable
 savings         in the administrative                      and other         expenditure            combined            with     the rationalization

 and overheads,                  however          unpalatable            some       of them         may       be.      This     is what       we do in          our

 6. 8          Mr.       President,             speaking         from       the long-ter-m             point        of view,       1 think     that     by decen-

in exchange              rates,        we consider             that     the additional            liability         should      be made         good byfurther

due to appreciation                     of the US dollar               in terms         of other          currencies           the deficit        is reduced
below        the estimated                figure       of $12,      652 million,            we consider               that    the additional            assess-

 12. 1 M.          DERRADJI               (Algérie)          :
         Monsieur           le President,                Mesdames                et Messieurs,               nous      aurions         souhaité            nous réunir
en session             extraordinaire               pour       méditer            sur   certains          grands        problèmes              qui préoccupent
actuellement              le monde            et qui      sont       en rapport            avec      les     activités        de l’Unesco,                 par    exemple
l’alphabétisation,                  l’application             de la science               au développement,                     la lutte        pour        la paix       et
la défense            des droits           de l’homme,                 l’évaluation            des activités            de l’Organisation                     depuis       sa
création,            et pour       leur      trouver         des       solutions         adéquates.              Hélas,       il n’en        est     rien      et foroe
nous       est de constater                 que d’autres               événements              ou preoccupations,                     dans      lesquels          la ma-
jorité       de nos pays             n’ont      aucune          responsabilité,                 nous     imposent           cette      session.
 12. 2 Nous             avons       sui:Ji     d’une      manière             soutenue          et régulière,            et non sans               inquietude,
l’évolution            de la crise           financière             de notre          Organisation,               crise      que nous            sommes           appelés
aujourd’hui              à examiner             à la lumière               des documents                qui nous         sont       soumis.
 12. 3       Malgré        tout     le soin        apporté           à la preparation                de ces documents                   et en dépit              de la
 qualité       du travail          auquel         se sont         livrés        leurs       auteurs,          travail      qui      constitue           le fruit       de
 leurs       méditations             et de leur          analyse           très     poussee          de la situation,                nous     ne saurions               en
 aucun       cas nous          rallier         à leurs        conclusions              sans       proceder          au préalable              à un examen
 critique         des causes             de cette        situation           et de ses          effets.        On ne saurait              en effet           prétendre
                                                                                      165


 3xc/3
 enrayer           une crise          sans      s’attaquer         à ses origines              ni prevenir             de nouvelles            causes        de
 difficultés.             On ne peut           non plus        ne pas        tenir    compte         d’effets         qui    risquent         tôt ou tard
 de donner            naissance           à des situations              plus      graves.
 12. 4       L’inflation          et la dévaluation,                qui sont        les    causes        de la crise            financière          de notre
Organisation,                 résultent         de crises         économiques              ou monétaires                dues      aux     systèmes           et
structures             que l’on        trouve        dans     certains         pays     developpes             et qui,       à leur       tour,      decoulent
d’un      système           monetaire            et financier         international             dont     tout     le monde           s’accorde           mainte-
nant      à reconnaftre               qu’il     est    inadéquat         et inopérant.
 12. 5 Les           pays       en voie       de développement                   ont durement             ressenti         les     effets      de cette       crise
sur     leur       Économie           et leur       commerce,             A present,            c’est      une partie           de leurs         activites
dans       les     domaines           educatif        et scientifique             qui va en subir              les     conséquences,                alors     qu’en
toute       logique        les    pays      développés,            qui     sont     à l’origine          de cette         crise,       d.evraient         en sup-
porter         la responsabilité                 et les     conséquences.
 12. 6 Pour             pallier       la crise        financière          de l’Organisation,                  on a recours             notamment             à ce
qu’on        appelle        des     “economies”.              Or,     il s’agit        en réalité          de compressions                  budgetaires,
de coupures               dans     le programme,                 car     les     mesures         qui tendent            à réduire          le programme
par     l’ajournement                ou l’annulation             d’activités          ne peuvent            etre     considérees             comme          des
economies.               A notre         avis,      il y a économie               quand      un projet          est     exécuté        dans      des     condi-
tions       noi.males            à un coQt inférieur                 à celui        qui   était     initialement             prevu.         Or,     les mesures
que l’on          nous      propose         ont un caractère                différent        et il conviendrait                 que l’on        s’entende
d’abord           sur    ce point.
 12. 7 Ces            mesures,           dans      leur     majorite,           touchent        des     secteurs          vitaux,        tels     que l’educa-
tion      et la science,              c’est-à-dire           des domaines               où les       pays       en voie        de développement                  res-
 sentent         le plus       grand       besoin       d’une      cooperation           internationale.                Elles       auront       donc     uneffet
fâcheux           sur    le programme                 en cours         et ne sont         nullement            conformes             à la politique           et à
l’orientation              generale         arrétées         notamment,              à sa dix-septième                   session,          par    la Conférence
 générale,            qui a recommande                   une amelioration                qualitative            et quantitative             du programme,
l’expansion              de l’activité           de l’Organisation                et la préservation                 de son autonomie.
 12.8        Les      mesures          prises        pour    arriver           à une     compression                de 5. 100.000              dollars        (cf.
3 XC/INF.              7, page        6) et pour          renvoyer          à l’exercice           ultérieur           certaines          activites        feront
supporter             au prochain           budget        la charge          des activités           ajournees,             diminuant           ainsi     la capa-
cité     de renouvellement                    du programme                 et nuisant         à sa qualité            ; et le taux          de croissance
du programme                   se trouve,           en raison         de ces mesures,                  réduit        à un taux         symbolique,              puis-
qu’il      est ramené             de 5, 66 ‘$‘oà 0, 84 70.
 12. 9 C’est            là une ironie             du sort,        car     au moment            méme         où l’on        s’inquiète          des     résultats
des premières                  annees        de la Deuxième                Décennie         du developpement                    et où l’on         essaie         de
pallier         leurs      insuffisances,               on assiste          à une régression                 sensible         des prévisions,                pour-
                                                                                  166


                                                                                                                                                              3XCl3
tant     modestes,           retenues          par    la Conférence               générale           dans     ce domaine.
 12. 10      Lors      de sa quinzième                 session         en effet,        la Conférence                générale,           en décidant           de
 contribuer         à la strategie             internationale              de la Deuxième                 Décennie           des     Nations         Unies     pour
le développement                 adoptée         par     l’Assemblée             générale           des     Nations        Unies       le 24 octobre             1970,
avait     declaré        que “le         succès       de la Deuxième                Décennie            pour      le développement                   dépendra
autant      de la qualité           de l’aide         fournie        aux pays          en voie        de developpement                   que du volume
des     ressources           dont     l’insuffisance              a éte déplorée.                 Tout     progrès         réalisé        sur    la voie       de la
paix     permettrait            de dégager           des moyens              propres           à accroftre           cette     aide”.
 12. 11      Parmi       les     principes          directeurs            arrétés        par      la Conférence               genérale        lors      de sa
 seizième        session,          nous      relevons           que le développement                      est un processus                de croissance
 et de changement,                 c’est-à-dire              de renovation,              que la qualité              de l’assistance               et le     vo-
lume      des    ressources              constituent           des    conditions           essentielles             du succès          de la Deuxième
Décennie,          que cette          aide     doit     représenter             au moins            1 % du produit             national        brutdespays
developpés          du point         de vue        économique              et technique.
 12. 12      Par    ailleurs,          lors     de sa dix-septième                    session,          la Conférence                générale         avait     re-
commandé,             dans      les     conclusions            du débat        de politique             générale          que,      compte         tenu     de
l’ampleur         des besoins              à satisfaire,           l’organisation                 puisse      disposer          de ressources               finan-
cières       adéquates           et qu’elle        puisse        compter          sur    un taux         de croissance               réelle       raisonnable
de son budget            ordinaire,            garant         de son autonomie                  ainsi     que de la qualité               et de l’efficacité
de son action.
 12. 13      L’Assemblee               générale          des Nations           Unies         avait     recommandé               de son côté            que le
taux     de croissance              annuelle         du produit           brut    de l’ensemble                des pays          en voie       de dévelop-
pement        pendant        la Deuxième              Décennie           soit    d’au      moins        6 %, avec          possibilité           de fixer        un
taux     plus    elevé      pour      la deuxième               moitié      de la      Décennie.
 12. 14 En adoptant                la stratégie             internationale            du developpement,                      1’Assemblee              generale
avait     solennellement               déclaré         : “Le      développement                  doit   avoir       pour      objectif       ultime       d’assu-
rer    de,s améliorations                  constantes           du bien-étre            de chacun            et d’apporter             à tous        des avan-
tages.      Si on laisse            se perpétuer              des privilèges              indus,        des extrémes               de richesses             et d’in-
justice       sociale,        le développement                   manquera           son but principal.                . . La communauté                    inter-
nationale        doit     se montrer             à la hauteur            des possibilités                sans      precedent           qu’offrent,         ànotre
époque,        la science           et la technique,               de façon         que pays          développes             et pays       en voie        de dé-
veloppement            puissent          jouir     équitablement               des progrès              de la science             et de la technique,
contribuant          ainsi       à accélérer           le développement                   économique              dans      le monde          entier,      . . La
responsabilite             principale           d’assurer          leur      propre        developpement                 incombe          aux pays         envoie
de développement                  eux-mémes               ainsi     qu’il     est    souligne         dans      la Charte           d’Alger         ; mais      si
 considérables            que soient           leurs       propres         efforts,         ils    ne suffiront           pas     à leur      permettre
d’atteindre         les     objectifs         de développement                  voulus          aussi     rapidement             qu’il    le faut       si les
                                                                                167


pays     développés              ne leur          viennent          pas     en aide        en mettant         à leur      disposition           davantage           de

12. 15       Il ne fait          aucun        doute       que nous           sommes          encore       bien    loin     d’atteindre           ces objectifs,

 12, 16 La          quatrième              Conference              des pays          non alignes          a donc      décidé        de demander              laréu-

 12. 17      Pour        des      raisons          de commodite                  et d’efficacité,          j’estime         qu’un      examen         de cette
situation         au niveau           de notre            Organisation              doit    étre    entrepris         parallèlement               à celui       des
Nations         Unies       et simultanément                      avec      lui    et je propose           à cet     effet      que le Directeur               géné-

loppement           , car       je doute          très      fort     que les        résultats        enregistrés           à ce jour         soient      satisfai-

Unies,        dans       le cadre            des résolutions                pertinentes           adoptées        par    la Conference              des pays
non alignés.
  12. 18      Monsieur             le Président,                pour      résorber          une bonne         partie       du déficit        du budget           de
l’organisation               dQ à la dévaluation,                       le recours           à l’ouverture           de crédits           supplémentaires
 s’avère        necessaire.                Une      contribution             supplémentaire               sera     donc      payee       par    les    Etats

il y en a huit             qui,      non seulement                  ne verseront             pas    de contribution              supplémentaire,                 mais

that      the fundamental                   reason          for     this      financial        crisis        is the uncertain               and unclear               interna-

relationship,                 and instead             it was         decided         to leave          the matter           to a committee                  for    another
year       before          the World            Bank        and Monetary                Fund         took     their      own decision.                  Mr.      President,
again       today          we note        with       dismay           the attitude           which        the big        powers          seem       to maintain.               They

 strument             for    international               peace         and understanding;                    just     as they         were       opposed          to the Spe-

violate          international              peace         and understanding,                      the peace          and understanding                     that      we     a11
desire.             We need            only      read        the     report         of the       Secretary-General                     of the        United        Nations
on the Economie                     and Social            Consequences                 of the Arms              Race       and of Military              Expenditures

terests           and resources                 to the social               and economic                development              not only          of their        own       na-
tions       but of the human                    race,        in order          to make        the lives           of their        citizens         and “neighbours”
worth         living.          It is only         by SO doing                that    everlasting             peace        and understanding                    cari     be
 achieved.               For     peace        Will      never         be achieved             by the sword               or by nuclear               weapons.              Only
 love      and understanding                     cari do SO.

  lest     co-operation.                 This      cari only         be done          by making               some        sacrifice.            We therefore                rec-

course,        this   would     necessitate         making     amendments            to Article      32 of our     Organization’s
