        Monsieur             le Président,                la délégation           polonaise          a suivi      avec        attention        et intérêt        les
interventions               du Directeur               général         et du vice-        président          du Conseil             exécutif        concernant
la situation           financière             de 1’Unesco             et les     mesures          qui ont été,            ou qui peuvent             êtreprises
pour      couvrir          le déficit          financier         de l’organisation.                 C’est      aussi        avec      un grand        intérêt      que
nous      avons        pris      connaissance                des débats          consacrés           à cette       question          lors     des 92e et          93e
 sessions         du Conseil              exécutif,          et que nous          avons      étudié       d’autres           documents           pertinents.
 24. 2 Nous            considérons                que les       problèmes           de la politique             rationnelle            dans     le    domaine
administratif               et financier             ainsi     que ceux         d’une      gestion       efficace          revêtent         une importance
 essentielle           pour       l’activité          pratique         de l’Organisation,               pour       son prestige              et son autorité
dans      le monde.             Ce problème,                  qui n’est       plus    uniquement             une question              de technique,           d’éta-
blissement             du budget              prend          chaque       année     plus      d’importance               politique.          Le fait      de   con-
voquer         une session              extraordinaire               pour     étudier       la situation           financière            de 1’Unesco         prouve
 que l’Organisation                    devrait         sérieusement             réfléchir         à ses      méthodes            de programmation,
 d’établissement                    du budget           et de gestion.            Nous     trouvons          que,       pour      l’Unesco,          le temps
 est   venu       de stabiliser               son budget,            de procéder            à une estimation                  plus     précise       de l’effica-
 cité   de la réalisation                    de son programme,                    ce qui assurerait                 une mise           à profit       optimale
 des moyens              financiers             dont     dispose        l’Organisation.
 24. 3 Malgré               une situation              incontestablement                difficile,          1’Unesco            est     en état       de faire
 face    aux      conséquences                  de la dévaluation               et de l’inflation.             Nous        avons        approuvé         les   pro-
 positions          d’économie               du Directeur             général,        adoptées         par     le Conseil             exécutif       à sa     93e
 session,          visant       le règlement                du déficit       budgétaire            causé      par     l’inflation.           De même,           nous
 notons        avec      satisfaction              la décision           du Conseil         exécutif        invitant         le Directeur            général        à
 réaliser         de nouvelles                 économies             de    1. 600.000          dollars        afin       de Couvrir            le    déficit
 causé        par     la     dévaluation              du dollar.            Tout     en     approuvant             entièrement               ce    programme,
 nous      considérons                cependant           que d’autres           possibilités          d’économies                ne sont       pas      encore
 épuisées.           Nous        sommes             d’accord         avec    l’opinion         du Directeur              général         sur    les    mesures
 d’économie             qui doivent              consister          à réaliser        le programme                établi,         d’une      façonmoins           COQ-
 teuse       que celle          prévue          dans      le budget,         sans     y apporter           toutefois           des modifications                plus
 importantes.                C’est       pourquoi           nous     voyons       surtout        de nouvelles             possibilités           d’economies
  dans     la réduction               des dépenses              administratives               qui,    à notre         avis,       sont     trop     grandes.
  24.4       Un programme                    visant       à des économies               supplémentaires                   devrait        prévoir        les   me-
  sures       suivantes            :
                                                                                   184


                                                                                                                                                                   3xci3
        1. Etant        donné       qu’environ           60% des dépenses                     de 1’Unesco              sont      destinées           à couvrir
            les     frais      afférents         aux    salaires           et aux honoraires,                    il faut        envisager           la    réduc-
            tion      de ces frais            en adaptant           le nombre             du personnel               aux besoins                réels      des acti-
            vités       de fond        de l’Organisation.
             C’est      à des possibilités                d’économies                dans      ce domaine              que faisait             allusion        le Di-
             recteur         général         de 1’Unesco           dans       son discours              à la 92e session                    du Conseil             exé-
             cutif,      en signalant            toutefois        les      conséquences               négatives            de la réduction                 du per-
             sonnel        pour     la réalisation            du programme.                     Nous       sommes             d’accord            qu’un      tel
             risque        existe       dans     le cas     où la réduction                  serait       effectuée            de façon           mécanique.
             11 me semble               qu’on      pourrait        éviter         un tel      danger         en liant          une réduction               raison-
             nable       du personnel             .à la simplification                   de la structure                trop      développée             du Secre-
             tariat       et à son adaptation                aux besoins               de la réalisation                  du programme                 actuel.
        2. La réduction                du personnel           aurait         pour       conséquence               de renoncer               à la construction
            du sixième            bâtiment          supplémentaire,                   ce qui permettrait                     d’économiser                les        dé-
            penses         pour      la construction             et plus          tard     pour      les     frais       d’entretien             du bâtiment.
        3. Dans        la situation           financière         actuelle,            particulièrement                    difficile,          de l’unesco,              il
            faut      abandonner            la pratique          qui consiste              à couvrir           les     dépenses             administratives
            liées      à la réalisation               des projets            du PNUD            et de la Banque                   mondiale           par    le      bud-
            get régulier             de 1’Unesco.            Ces       prestations             devraient            étre      remboursées                à 100%
            par      lesdites        organisations,              et non pas              seulement             à 40%           comme           cela      a lieu
            maintenant.
        4. Le Secrétariat                 de 1’Unesco           devrait          utiliser        à une plus            vaste        échelle        les     comptes
            en valeurs            nationales           dans    les      Etats       membres             dont      la monnaie               n’est     pas conver-
            tible,       en organisant              dans    ces Etats             un plus        grand        nombre            de conférences                 et de
             séminaires               et    en s’y       procurant             le     matériel           et l’équipement                     nécessaire              à
            l’organisation.
24. 5 La réalisation                   des propositions                 citées       ci- dessus           pourrait           sinon        totalement            liqui-
der,      du moins           limiter         au maximum               le montant            des contributions                    supplémentaires,                     car
ces    contributions             sont     une charge          considérable                 pour     les     Etats        membres.
24. 6 La Pologne                 avec      beaucoup         d’autres           pays       a attiré       l’attention             sur     la nécessité              de
freiner       le rythme           d’accroissement                du budget             régulier         de l’Unesco,                 et de le baser                sur
des critères            rationnels           et économiquement                     justifiés.          Comme           beaucoup              d’autres        Etats
 membres,             nous     considérons             que la situation                financière           de l’Organisation                     devrait          être
 l’émanation           de la situation             financière            et économique               de ses membres.                        Le critère            géné-
 ralement        connu        et admis          de l’estimation               et de l’accroissement                         économiques                est      l’in-
 dice    d’accroissement                 du produit         national.            Ainsi,        c’est      autour        de l’accroissement                      moyen
 du produit         national        des Etats          membres             que devrait           osciller          le degré           d’accroissement                   du
                                                                                 185


3XCl3
budget        de 1’Unesco.            Cependant,             onle     sait,     le taux         d’accroissement                 du budget         de 1’Unesco
pour      les    années        1973-     1974 depasse              plusieurs          fois       cet indice.          Nous       voudrions            en ce lieu
mettre        en garde       contreles         résultats         dangereux           du développement                  d’un tel rythme               d’accrois-
sement          du budget.          De nombreux              pays,       et parmi          eux la Pologne,                  qui   remplissent              pleine-
ment       leurs     obligations           envers        l’Organisation,               ont des difficultés                   pour      faire     face      auxdé-
penses         de 1’Unesco           qui progressent               d’une      façon       aussi        rapide.
24. 7 La pratique                 d’un    accroissement                trop     important             du budget         de 1’Unesco            n’a pas        sauve
non plus         notre      Organisation           d’une        grave       crise      financière.               Le   Directeur             général         indique
que cet accroissement                     élevé      du budget           est,     entre       autres,          le resultat         de l’inflation             ou de
la dévaluation             du dollar,         Pourtant,nous               ne pouvons              admettre          que les        conséquences                dela
crise       monétaire          occidentale          retombent             sur     les     pays        qui n’en        sont       pas       responsables,
dont     les     pays     socialistes          et les       pays    en voie         de developpement.                      Nous      considérons              aussi
qu’aucun          Etat     membre          de 1’Unesco            ne devrait          en tirer           des avantages               financiers,            comme
 c’est     le cas actuellement.
 24. 8 Monsieur               le Président,              nous     nous      rendons           compte          de la quantité             immense            de be-
 soins       et de problèmes               qui se posent            à la société             internationale              dans le domaine                de l’édu-
 cation,        de la culture           et de la science.                Nous       comprenons                aussi     l’importance              qu’attachent
 les    pays      en voie       de développement                  à l’aide       qu’ils        reçoivent          dans ces domaines                  par l’inter-
 médiaire          de 1’Unesco.            C’est       pourquoi,          comme          je l’ai        expliqué        précédemment,                   nous nous
 prononçons            fermement            pour      l’élargissement                de l’activité             de l’organisation                 au moyen           de
 la réduction            des dépenses            administratives,                   pour       la réalisation              totale       des     programmes
  dont    bénéficient           surtout      les    pays       en voie       de développement.                      De vastes            possibilités           nou-
 velles        pour    l’élargissement               de l’aide         dans      ce domaine               sont     créees        par     la propositiondu
  ministre         des Affaires           étrangéres            de l’URSS,            André          Gromyko,            présentee            à la tribunede
  1’ONU        et concernant           la réduction             des budgets            militaires            des    cinq       membres           permanents
  du Conseil          de Sécurité           et l’utilisation            d’une      partie         des moyens             obtenus          pour     l’aide       aux
  pays      en voie       de développement.                   Le Gouvernement                     de la République                populaire           de Pologne
  ainsi      que l’opinion           publique       polonaire           donnent        leur        plein     appui       à cette        proposition.
  24. 9 Monsieur               le Président,              la délégation            polonaise            a présenté            son point        de vue sur les
  problèmes           essentiels          de la politique            financière            de 1’Unesco.              En formulant              nos opinions
  et nos propositions,                 nous      avons        été guides          par     l’intérêt         de l’Organisation,                   par     le désir
  de renforcer             son autorité          dans       le monde            et d’apporter               une contribution                 constructive           à
  l’amélioration             de l’efficacité            pratique         de l’activité             de 1’Unesco.              En ce qui          concerneles
  problèmes           qui ont été évoqués,                    nous     sommes           prêts        à coopérer             avec    les      autres       Etats
  membres           et avec        le Secrétariat             de 1’Unesco           dans       leurs      efforts      visant       à la réalisation              com-
  mune        des tâches         résultant        de l’Acte         constitutif          de 1’Unesco.              Merci        Monsieur            le Président.

and training            in the development                     of human          resources             and human              dignity.         As the nations

recognize           that      the operation              of the affairs            of Unesco              is    directly         related       to the economic

 30.1      M.     GREGUS               (Tchecoslovaquie)                   :
         Monsieur            le Président,               la troisième            session         de la Conference                    générale         extraordi-
naire      se réunit            dans     des conditions               internationales                très       difficiles.         D’un      côté,      nous
 sommes          témoins           du grand         effort        que les       pays       socialistes               et quelques          autres       pays     de-
ploient       pour       la paix        et pour        la cooperation               internationale,                  contre      le colonialisme,                le
fascisme           et l’apartheid             - et il s’agit             là de problèmes                   qui figurent            tous     au programme
 de 1’Unesco.              De l’autre          côté,        au contraire,               nous    voyons           les     agissements             de ceux      pour
lesquels         la paix         - et c’est         le moins           qu’on       puisse       dire       - n’est         pas la considérationprin-
 cipale      quand        il s’agit       de la situation               internationale.                Il suffit,         dans      cet ordre         d’idees,       de
 mentionner            la guerre           qui    sévit       au Moyen-            Orient,        où le peuple               arabe      est obligé         de dé-
 fendre       durement             ses    droits        internationaux               contre      l’imperialisme                   d’Israe1.
 30. 2 La         situation          financière            à laquelle         1’Unesco          et les         autres        organisations            internatio-
 nales      doivent         faire      face    est la conséquence                     directe         des      contradictions              qui    existent        au
                                                                                    189


sein     du monde              capitaliste.           Ces     problèmes             sont     étrangers            aux pays         socialistes,            qui
organisent              leur     économie           conformément                à un plan           dont     le but principal              est l’élévation
systématique                 du niveau         de vie       de leurs         peuples.          La     situation         dans     laquelle        nous      nous
trouvons             aujourd’hui           peut    malheureusement                     se repéter            régulièrement.                La conséquence
en est que les                pays      en voie        de développement                   et les      pays       à Économie           planifiée       en seront
toujours           les    victimes.
  30. 3 Monsieur                 le Président,             la Tchécoslovaquie                     n’est       certes       pas indifférenteàlaques-
 tion    de l’exécution                ou de la non-             exécution         du programme                   de 1’Unesco.             Mais    la    Tchéco-
 slovaquie            ne veut        pas    gaspiller          les    ressources             qui proviennent                du travail         de toutenotre
 société         socialiste.
 30.4       En ce qui concerne                     le programme                 de l’Unesco,              il doit      toujours        découler         des
 axiomes            fondamentaux              qui     sont     inscrits        dans      l’Acte       constitutif.           Ces     axiomes          doivent
 être    à la base            du programme                 de l’Organisation,                   tel   qu’il      doit     se développer            dans       cer-
 tains     domaines             prioritaires             et dans        certaines          parties        du monde.            Un de ces          axiomes
fondamentaux                  est qu’il       faut     créer       et garantir           des conditions               propres         à assurer          le dé-
 veloppement                et la collaboration                 pacifique         dans      le monde.             C’est     pourquoi         la   tâche       la
 plus     sérieuse            qui incombe            à 1’Unesco            se situe         dans     le secteur            des sciences           sociales         :
la recherche                interdisciplinaire                 complexe           qu’implique             l’étude        des problèmes             mondiaux,
 politiques            et sociaux            doit     être     notre      tâche       permanente.                Par    l’analyse          de ces problèmes,
 on peut        toujours           arriver        à la définition            des problèmes                  particuliers           à résoudre           dans       les
 autres        secteurs           d’activité         de 1’Unesco             et     arriver          ainsi       à formuler            le programme                 de
 l’Organisation                tout     entière.
 30. 5 Il importe                  que les       Etats      membres             réfléchissent              à tout      cela    et en tirent          des conclu-
 sions,        sinon       pour      le programme                 actuel,        du moins           pour      la préparation              du programme
futur.
 30. 6 Lors              de la 93e session                du Conseil            exécutif,          au cours          de laquelle          a été décidee            la
 convocation              de la présente              session         extraordinaire                de la Conférence                générale,          onabeau-
 coup     discuté          les    issues       possibles           de la situation             financière.             On a trouvé           lesmoyens             de
 couvrir        l’inflation          et on en a cherché                d’autres        pour       abaisser          le déficit       résultant       de la déva-
luation.          A cet égard,              il faut      absolument             donner        la priorité           à la recherche              des moyens            à
 employer             pour      accroi’tre,          dans      tous     les    domaines            de réalisation             du programme,                l’effica-
 cité    du Secrétariat                 et de ses         experts         et pour       découvrir             ainsi     des réserves             supplémen-
taires        permettant              de diminuer            les    effets       de la        dévaluation.              Il   faut     que     chaque         Etat
membre              procède,          de ce point          de vue,          à la réévaluation                 de chaque         action       de 1’Unesco
 dans      son propre             milieu       et à la préparation                   réfléchie         des programmes                    futurs.
 30.7       Il faut        que les        commissions              nationales           deviennent             de véritables            instruments             de
propagande,                capables          de mobiliser              efficacement              toutes       les    forces       qui peuvent           être
                                                                                   190


                                                                                                                                                               3XCl3
mises        au service            de l’Éducation,               de la science,             de la culture              et de la lutte            pour      la
paix      et pour      la coopération                 internationale.              C’est      ainsi       que pourront              être    accomplies
à temps,          rationnellement                 et energiquement,                   les    tâches         immenses             de notre      Organisa-
tion,      tâches       qui,      dans      le passé,          me paraissent               avoir       souvent         et6 oubliees            ou sous-
estimées.           Je vous          remercie,             Monsieur          le Président.

 32.1          Mr.     MARSHALL-MALAGOLA                                  (International             Association             of Art):
               Mr.     President,              1 thank       you    for    your      courtesy          in allowing            me to have           your       atten-

phone.          You     may       wonder         what       a non-governmental                    association             of artists        could      have       to
say     that     was     relevant          to a finance            meeting.          Let     me explain.
32.2          Not     only     my      organization,              but many          more       like     us,      actually         assume        considerable
parts       of Unesco’s             programme;               we take        them      on our        own       shoulders           and we hand            them
back      to you when             we have         completed            them,       to be inscribed                in the Director-General’s
Report        as part        of the activities                of Unesco.            This      is a successful                and traditionalprocess;
we are        part     of Unesco,              and there          are    clear      directives            about      our     responsibility            to support        -
and     where        necessary              carry         out    - those       parts      of the programme                     which       comewithin             our
professional             competence.
32. 3          In return         for     this    support,          and indeed           to enable          us to give          it in an effective               way,
Unesco          earmarks            certain       sums        as fixed        subventions             and certain            other       sums      for    contracts
for    specific        projects.              Both      the contracts            and the subventions                   bring        to you,       from       an ef-
ficient        non-governmental                    organization,               returns        of a very           high     professional            quality        for
a very        small       cost.        NGOs        are      not rewarded             at commercial                 rates;       they     are    largelyvolun-
tary      organizations              supported            by unpaid         work.         We welcome                the opportunity              which        our
collaboration             with      you     gives        us to carry          our    professional               services          to a wider         public.         But
whatever          financial          troubles          affect      Unesco        at this      moment,             a11 the NGOs             in your       system
suffer       in exactly          equal       proportion.
32. 4         We suffer            the effects            of inflation        and we are            tied      to the dollar;            and we cannot              take
independent            action        to salvage            our   budget        when      this     currency           falls,       as you      cari..      Why?
Because          our     dollars         corne      from       you.
32. 5         1 should        like      to appeal          to this      honourable           Conference              to put our          minds       at rest        on
one point.           During          this      meeting,         you Will,         1 am sure,             finally      approve          a supplementary
                                                                                 193


3XCf3
sum     to preserve         the Organization’s            programme            as a whole.          Will     our    subventions          and
our    contracts,       which     are   an integral         part     of your      programme,             benefit     by the same           pro-
portional       increases       during     the current         biennium?
32. 6        This    question     1 ask    with      especial     urgency       for,    as far     as my organization                 (the    In-

difference        between      keeping      alive     in 1974 and having             to close      down.         1 am sure        that    many

of your      programme          - are    in the same          situation.         Thank      you,    Sir.

 (4. 1)      Mr.       PEREZ            HERNANDEZ                   (Spain)        (Translation             from the Spanish):
         Mr.       President,             the Spanish              Government             supports          the proposal,                submitted          to this session              of
 the General              Conference            by the Executive                  Board,         for supplementaryestimates                            totalling         $14,252,100,
 in accordance                with the terms                 of document             3 XC/4.
 (4. 2) My Government                        has SO decided                because          it believes            this to be the surest                   course         to follow,
 from      both the political                 and the technical                  points       of view.           Generally            speaking,          economic            problems
 give rise in our Organization                               to different          attitudes.           One, which               might        be described             as idealistic,
 is held by those whose                       main concern                is for the Organization’s                         lofty      aims,      in comparison                with which
 a11 means            are slight.            In this connexion,                   the delegation               of Spain is of the opinion                       that there         exists
 at present           no body better                qualified         than Unesco              to work         for the integration                 in development                of a11
  ihe countries              of the world,              in the spheres               of education,              science         and culture.             Because           it pursues
 tnis aim,          Unesco          is deserving                of financial         sacrifices           and efforts.                  This has always                 been the view
 taken by my country.
  (4. 3) There             is also another                 attitude      towards          the Organization’s                    financial        problems,             which       might
 be called          realistic.            According              to this attitude,              aims      and ideals            by themselves               do not suffice            to
 justify       an undertaking,                 but it is essential                 to establish            an efficient            mechanism,               a rhythm,           discipline
  in operation,              and interna1            and external              controls          for the execution                 of programmes.                     Unless       a11 this
  is assured,             an increase            in resources               Will inevitably             deflect         the     Organization            from        its aims.
  (4. 4) My country                   has also understood                    that this latter              attitude,          if it does not become                     a pretext,         is
  wise and compatible                     with the former                 one.        The present              situation          provides         proof         of this.          Con-
  sequently,            the agreement                on the additional                savings         requested            from       the Secretariat               of $1,600,000,
  has,     in our view,               a symbolic              as well as a numerical                     significance.                 It might       have been decided                  to
  cal1 for savings,                which        the Director-General                          himself           considered              at one time,                 of more           than
   $2,100,000;               or it could have been argued                            that any savings                  required           of the Organization                 would
  appreciably             affect       the programme.                    But political             common sense prevailed,                           in the preparation                  of
  these financial              documents,                on the part both of the Secretariat                                and of the Executive                    Board.        And an
  eclectic        formula          was evolved,                 proving       not only,           as SO often happens,                      the most         appropriate           but
  also,      it seems          to me,        the      fairest.
   (4. 5) This           political        wisdom           was moreover                matched,           in the opinion               of my delegation,                  by technical
  wisdom.            Different           methods           were      used      to tope        with     the     deficit       due     to inflation          of the       CurrencY         of
                                                                                            204


                                                                                                                                                                                         3XCl4
payment             and to devaluation                 of the currency                   of accounting               - for these two phenomena,though                                 related,
 are not identical.                  Devaluation             depends           more          on circumstances,                     is more           accidental,               it    may not
 happen         for years          and then recur                unexpectedly;                   whereas           inflation        is a virtually           endemic,             permanent,
 constant           phenomenon,                and is to some extent                       foreseeable.
 (4. 6) The draft                resolution           now before              us deals,            then with inflation                 as a foreseen             phenomenon.                And
 it makes           use of the Appropriation                         Reserve            approved            by the seventeenth                  session          of the General
 Conference              for our semi-full                 budgeting            system.             What was not foreseen                        was the           increase           in the
 speed with which                  the inflationary                spiral       developed.                 In accordance               with a certain                interna1         logic,
the deficit             caused       by accelerated                inflation          is mainly            absorbed           by administrative                   savings;            these
 cancel        out the roughly                 8 million        dollars         deficit.
 (4. 7) TO tope with the devaluation                                   of the currency                  of accounting,                which      could not be foreseen                         at
the time when the current                           budget         was established,                    an exceptional                measure           has been taken:                    an
extraordinary                 budget        has been established                       totalling,           as has already               been mentioned,                    less than the
actual        figure        of the deficit.
 (4. 8) It is not for us, at this extraordinary                                           session,           to make a detailed                  examination                 of the con-
sequences              of this different              technical           approach             to our large             deficit.         This Will no doubt be done by
the eighteenth                session          of the General               Conference.                 On the other              hand,       1 think       it fitting         to touch on
some of the most urgent                           questions           that have been brought                          to light       at this extraordinary                       session.
Will      it be necessary,                  for instance,              to convene               an extraordinary                  session        of the General                  Conference
on every            occasion         when our currency                      of accounting                is devalued?                Will it be advisable,                      in view         of
the speed with which                       the inflationary                spiral        is developing,                to use full budgeting                    instead          of semi-full
budgeting?                Will Unesco’s              index       of expansion                 continue         to float       freely,        as one more                 figure,         or Will
it be endowed                with flexibility             according            to circumstances?
(4. 9) In the view                  of my delegation,                   the change              in the unit of accounting                       entails        a problem               affecting
the United             Nations        system         as a whole,              and the risks                 attendant         on the taking             of an isolated                stand by
any one organization                       make such a course                       inadvisable.                Our Organization                  should          therefore            take no
action        for the moment                   on the question               in general,                but should              concentrate             on considering                     what
methods            it would        be most beneficial                    for us to apply.
  (4. 10) Meanwhile                   we should          use this opportunity                        for devising               a procedure              which          Will function
  automatically              in cases of officia1                 devaluation               of the currency                of accounting.               This procedure                    might
  consist         in fixing       a percentage             of devaluation                 following           which       Unesco        Will automatically                    absorb         the
  deficit       by distributing               the cost among the Member                               States.          Approval          by the Executive                   Board        would
  suffice        to bring       this mechanism                  into operation                 and, for the better                safeguarding             of national            interests~,
  it might be stipulated                     that any such agreement,                            to be valid,             would       require         to be approved                     by a
  specified           majority        in the Board.
  (4. 11) As a result                  of this or some similar                          arrangement,                 the convening             of an extraordinary                       ses-
  sion of the General                   Conference            would         only become               necessary             by reason          of the devaluation                    of the
  currency            of accounting             when the rate of that devaluation                                is such as to confront                      the Organizahion
  with a new financial                   situation.
  (4. 12) As regards                   inflation,         the most immediate                        lesson        to be learnt            from      the procedure                  being
  proposed            to us is the need for balance.                             Not a11 the items                   of the budget           are equally               affected         by
  inflation.            The index of inflation                   is not as simple                   as the index of devaluation                         and its components
  are therefore              heterogeneous.                  Moreover             it is by its very nature                       constantly           shifting,           and varies
  from       one country            to another.             It may perhaps                    be advisable             in future        to draw a distinction,                       within
  the Organization’s                  budget,         between          different           types       of goods and services,                      according              to vulnera-
  bility     to inflation          and also to the monetary                           area to which               they are related,                   on the grounds                    that
  certain         areas      may be regarded                   as being immune                     to the effects             of inflation.          This technical                 division
  of the budget             may make it easier                     to calculate              the foreseeable                indices        of inflation.               But the imme-
  diate task is to take measures                             for curtailment                   and saving,             which       is more        difficult           than simply             to
  accept        the economic              spiral       as an inevitable                  evil.
  (4. 13)        Inflation       may perhaps               be regarded               as the expression,                     in economic            terms,           of a problem
  affecting          the whole of Western                    civilization              - that of limits.                 A development                that is unaware                  of its
                                                                                                205


 3xc/4
limits      cannot be considered               as such.          Freedom,           knowledge,        progress,        if they are to be construc-
 tive, must form part of a process of balance;                                  otherwise        they lose their human character                       and take
 on that of natural phenomena.                       Thus it is that, in the most exemplary                          undertakings,            quantity      must
 be allied to quality,              sometimes         yielding       first place to the latter.                And SO Unesco’s              index of expan-
 sion must take account of a11 the vectors                             of economic          growth,     as well as those of the Organiza-
 tion’s qualitative             performance.
 (4. 14) This is the third extraordinary                           session of the General Conference                       that has taken place in
 Unesco’s        lifetime.          Twenty years have passed since we last had recourse                                        to this exceptional
 measure         - twenty years during which the Organization                                 has grown and matured.                   It is in my opinion
 symptomatic             that the reason for convening this conference                              should have been economic.                      The size
 of our budget is such that exceptional                          measures          must inevitably          be taken to deal with the anomalies
 that may occur in the course of the budgetary                                 period.        It is not a matter of a small figure to be
 absorbed,          reduced or increased,                nor of a small unit that is frozen.                       Fifteen million            dollars      re-
 presents       an important           amount in terms of human activity                          and interests.          The reason for this meet-
 ing therefore            affords proof, 1 am happy to say, of Unescols                              objective      value.
  (4. 15) But this extraordinary                   session is also a sign of concern for legality,                              for the Constitution
 of Unesco.           The work entailed by the organization                            of the Conference,             the thousands              of dollars
 expended on its preparation,                    the disturbance              caused to national delegations                  and to the Secretariat               -
 a11 this 1 should like to interpret                    as proof of the qualitative                 factors to which 1 have just referred.
  It is the sacrifice            made by Unesco out of regard for its own dignity.                                  In this way, 1 hope, contri-
 buting to bestow upon Unesco the tradition                               of humanism           which we desire that it should have. Thank
 you, Mr. President.

 of the       Executive            Board,       and      Mr.       Ren6       Maheu,          Director-General                of the       Organization.
 We approve             in general        the resolution              contained         in the recommendation                   (document            3 XC/4)
 adopted        by the Executive               Board        at its       93rd     session        concerning         the possible             solutions        to
 the financial             problems         confronting           the Organization.
 6. 2          The      Chinese        delegation         holds        that    in approaching             this    problem,          the wishes           and
 desires        of the majority              of Member             States       should       be regarded          as the starting               point,      and
 that    full    consideration             should       be given          to the demands             of the developing               countries          in
 whatever           related        measures         we may          take.        Only      by SO doing         Will    we be        able      success-
fully     to realize           the aims       of the Organization.                    Therefore,         concretely          speaking,          in order        to
 caver       the deficit          caused      by inflation            and the devaluation                of the US dollar,               it seems         to us
that     both      further        economies         (namely,          doing      as much         as we cari but at as little                    cost    as pos-
 sible)      and an additional               appropriation              are     indispensable.              As to the possible                 reduction
 or deferment               of some        of the programme                   activities,         the following          two     principles           should
                                                                                 206


                                                                                                                                                              3XCl4
be duly         taken     into     account:          (1)     the volume             of reduction           should       not be enormous,                   and the
implementation                of the original              programme                should      not be seriously                damaged;             (2)    the
decision          as to the        items       to be reduced              should        be made         through          consultation           based       on the
real      interests         of the      Member           States       concerned,             particularly            those      of the developing
countries.             The     items        of which         they     are     in urgent         need      or which         are      in the process             of
implementation                should        not be reduced.                  If reduction           is necessary,               it should        be limited
to the minimum.                    Thank        you,      Mr.      President.

 tasks        entrusted        to it.       Numerous             sessions,            some      of them         characterized               by heated         dis-
 cussions          and late       hours,         took      place      in order         to scrutinize            the biennial            and long-term
 objectives          of the Organization                   and the budget               allocated         for    their     implementation.                   How-
 ever,        the strenuous             efforts       of delegates             and the Director-General                         and his       staff     were       not
 left    unrewarded.                We believe            that    the aeventeenth                session         of the General              Conference            was
 able      to concentrate             on major           topics       of priority,           and special            note     should       also     be made          of
 the greater           number          of important             resolutions            that    were       adopted         with     the full      knowledge           of
 their       implications.

  ing the efficiency                of the      Secretariat          ” in the implementation                       of‘the      biennial        programme.

more        usual        - to curtail             or postpone             the programmes                  agreed          upon       after        much        discussion            at the
General           Conference,                 to the detriment                of our aspirations.
(10. 4) On the other                       hand,        the need to find a more                      stable       solution          for the problem                  of the currency
of accounting                 is a matter             which       we must begin to tackle                      forthwith.                 We are aware                  of what           this
means,           of the projections                    involved,           and of the difficulties                   in the way of finding                     a satisfactory               solu-
tion.         There        Will need to be a11 kinds                        of negotiations              within         the United            Nations         family;       or else we
must begin to think                       in terms          of the course             suggested           by the Director-General                            in the statement                  he
made yesterday:                       freezing          the rate of exchange                   at the time when the budget                              is adopted          by the Gen-
eral      Conference.                   In oui- view,            this might          be a feasible             and relatively                 simple       method          of ensuring
that future            sessions             of the General              Conference            are not faced                 with      problems             like       the     one now
before         us.
(10. 5) In seeking                     a more          stable      solution,         we must reach                 agreement              on what Unesco’s                   growth          rate
is to be.            We have already                     spoken        of the difficulty             of fixing          a growth          rate that is compatible                        with
the reality            of world            development              and with the urgent                  needs         of the Member                  States       receiving          assis-
tance from              Unesco.              But these efforts                Will have been in vain if, shortly                                  after     the General             Con-
ference          has approved                  the growth           rate,     programmes                 are curtailed,                thus diminishing                  the hopes we
have placed               in Unesco.
 (10. 6) Lastly,                  we are deeply                convinced          that efforts           must continue                to be made to find ways and
means          of executing               the Organization’s                  programme               more        efficiently.              We must eradicate                    a11 super-
fluous        bureaucracy                 which        may impair            Unesco’s           efficiency           and lead to a decline                           in its       positive
achievements                   in the Field.              We cannot          afford       to use to no advantage                        the slender             resources           avail-
able to us which                    yet represent               a burden        for Member                States         such as Costa               Rica.
 (10. 7) 1 should                 like also to point out that certain                              Member            States       have benefited                 from      the difficul-
ties by which                 we are now beset:                     the contribution               they make to Unesco                         is not a real one, because
their       currencies               have been re-valued                     and the contribution                     they actually              pay does not represent                       any
 sacrifice          for them.                On the other            hand,       for the majority                 of countries              like ours,            the supplementary
contribution               does constitute                 a heavy         burden,        but one which                we are nevertheless                       prepared          to shoul-
der in order                to support            Unesco         and to further             its aims,           in the hope that                   formulas           may       be found
that Will be more                       propitious            and more          equitable          for a11 Member                  States           and especially                for        the
developing             countries.
 (10. 8) 1 repeat                 that our delegation                   Will vote in favour                  of the draft               resolutions               contained           in       the
various          documents                submitted           for our considerations;                      and 1 emphasize                    that it is not desirable                      at
this juncture                to embark             on a technical             examination              designed            to lead to further                  curtailments              or to
 make changes                   in the recommendations                         presented            by the Executive                  Board.            Thank        you very          much.

  cussed        for     a certain           time      at sessions           of the General                Conference             and of the Executive
  Board.           It deals         with      the surmounting                of the financial               situation         of the      Organization                 which
  for    years        has disquieted                many       of the Member                  States.        1 think       we are        justified           in express-
  ing    our     thanks         to the members                  of the Executive                  Board,       to the Director-General                            and his
  collaborators               in the Secretariat                  for   the efforts             they     have     made        in order          to analyse             the
  financial          situation          of the Organization.
  12.2         In considering                  further       the reasons            for      the financial           deficit,         it should            be asserted
 that     they      arise        out of the permanent                    monetary              crisis       of    the      capitalist             system           and
  longstanding              inflation.            There       cari be no doubt                that     these     factors         have      a detrimental                  ef-
  fect     on the activities                 of the Organization.                     My Government                  holds        the view             that   neither
  the German              Democratic               Republic          nor    other        socialist         countries,            which       have         a steady

(14. 1) Mr. EL-KHALIFAH                               (Democratic            Republic          of the Sudan) (Translation                        from       the Arabie):
        Mr.     President,            the present            budgetary         crisis      of the Organization                    is actually           the result         of the
monetary          policy       of the Great            Powers,          a policy       over which           we in the developing                     nations         have no
control.         This means             that,      when we pay our share                      of the supplementary                      estimates,            we do SO be-
cause we are forced                   to do it as a result                 of economic            and financial           conditions            which       are beyond              our
control.       We of the developingnations                          are more conscious than the others of the reductions                                                  and cuts
made in the programme.                           The so-called              “savings”          with reference              to the reductions                   in the pro-
gramme          are not really             savings        since they are realized                     to the detriment                 of the programme                        and
since they reduce                the rate of growth                  approved         by the General             Conference               at its seventeenth                 session
from       over 5. 5 per cent to less than 1 per cent.                                   But we find ourselves                         compelled             to accept             the
proposals          submitted          by the Executive                 Board      and to pay our share                   of the supplementary                        estimates,
while      we reserve            our right         to disapprove             any further           cuts in the programme                            and hope             that       the
Organization            Will strive           to tut down its administrative                         expenses,           which         unduly        burden        its budget,
We also sincerely                 hope that the Secretariat                      Will see to it that the programme                                cuts and reductions
are restored            in the Organization’s                    budget for 1975-19’76.
 (14. 2) Mr.          President,            our agreement                to pay this        share        of the supplementary                      estimates            does not
mean that we consider                     this solution            an ideal        one.      We rather          believe          it is a provisional                  solution,
which       should      be followed             by serious          studies       to be conducted             jointly       with the mother                   Organization
and the       other      Specialized            Agencies,           with a view to finding                 a permanent                solution         to the financial
problem         of the Organization.                     Thank        you, Mr.         President.

  16. 1        Mr.       YAQUB            KHAN           (Pakistan):
                Mr.         President,              at this        stage      in the        discussion,              the        issues          before           this      extra-
  ordinary          session          ofthe        General          Conference             have        already        been          put with           remarkable                 clarity
  in the      statements             made         by His        Excellency              Mr.      Betancur         Mejfa,             by the Director-General
 and by the distinguished                           delegates            who have          preceded           me.          Although            there         is very          little
 that     could      be added            by way          of a new          dimension             to the discussion,                      one feels            compelled               to
  speak      because           of the momentous                      nature         of the problem               before            this     Conference                 and be-
  cause      of deep          concern           about       its    numerous             implications             for      the current                as well           as the fu-
  ture     shape       of Unesco’s                endeavour             in various           fields.
  16. 2         Sir,      it is no small                matter         if the General               Conference               finds        within         a year         of ap-
  proving        the programme                     of the Organization                    for      the current             biennium,                as well          as the
  outlines        of its      activities            for    some         years       to corne,           that    the executive                  body        responsible
  for    implementing                its    directives             is faced         with      such       a large        financial             deficit         caused         by
  factors       completely              beyond          the control            of the Organization.                         The        instability             of the world
  monetary           system          and the present-day                       uncertainties               resulting             from        it are        objective             facts
  of our      existence.               The       factors         responsible             for     this     state     of affairs               are     numerous              and
  complex          and their           solutions           lie    in areas          of international               activity             on which            Unesco           cari
  hardly       have       any direct             influence.              But    this     situation          does      confront              us    with      a very          clear
  choice:           do we succumb                    to the pressures                  caused         by the vagaries                    of the financial                  world
  or do we resolve                  to keep           our     faith      in tha      ideals        of Unesco           in a manner                   strong         enough           to
  withstand          these        pressures?
                                                                                       216


16. 3           Sir,       to us the answer                    is simple             and unequivocal.                   It is a11 the more                  important
that      the programmes                      of Unesco             are       preserved           and strengthened                     SO that      in time            they
create         the kind            of consciousness                    a11 the world              over      that      is essential            to progress,                  to de-
velopment               and to peace.                   The      magnitude              of the deficit            and the causes                leading          to it are
not of such              a nature           as to admit              of a solution,               as the Director-General                          pointed            out,       by
inner        adjustments                only,        nor      could      they       be overcome               by some          fiats     of management.                       There
is,      in our        opinion,           no escape             from        the need          to generate             additional          funds        and my            delega-
tion      would,          therefore,             lend       its    full      support         to the supplementary                       demands.
 16.4           We are            in full      sympathy              with       the constructive                line     of thinking            suggested              by our
distinguished                  colleagues             that      every         possible         effort      should        be made           to enforce             interna1
economy              and to rationalize                    the expenditure                   of the Organization,                      but we have              taken         due
note       of the fact             that    the Director-General                           has already             given      his     utmost        attention              to this
 problem.               He had,           in fact,         already            frozen        a substantial             number           of vacant          posts,           he had
 reduced           the number               of meetings,                 eliminated             or postponed               a considerable                 number             of
 publications                and brought              about        effective           reductions           in the expenditure                   on staff           travel.
 We are           sure        that    he Will          continue          his      efforts       in this       direction          to bring         about        whatever
 economy             is possible.
  16. 5          I am anxious                to point          out,       Sir,      that     the support            we are         giving       to the supplemen-
 tary       demands             is by no           means           easy       for     us.      We are         struggling            hard      to recover               from         the
 ravages            of the worst              floods         in our         history        and every           single       dollar        counts         in our          national
 rehabilitation                 effort.
 16. 6          Again,           the monetary                  situation           which       has brought             about       this     crisis,         and which                fre-
 quently          militates           against          the interests                of developing              countries,             is not of our              making.             Nor,
 in fact,          is it strictly             equitable            that      the developing               countries          should         also      have        to raise
 their       contributions.                   But we would                  like      to see      Unesco          in terms           of reference              which           go far
 beyond         the doctrine                of the affluent                 countries           assisting          the developing               countries              in their
 economic              fields.          We believe               that      the work           of Unesco           is vital        to the developed                    as ,well         as
 the developing                   world,        and therefore                   we are         more      than       ready       to participate               in this          joint
 effort       to preserve                the integrity               and momentum                   of these          programmes.
  16. 7          This        is an extraordinary                        situation          caused       by some            extraordinary                 developments                   in
  the financial                world.         While         we hope            that     the world          of finance           stabilizes           itself,          we have           to
  take      into      account          the possibility                that       the present           crisis        may      recur        from        time        to time.             It
  is therefore                imperative             that      a cool         and dispassionate                   analysis          of Unesco’s             financial             lia-
  bilities        is carried             out and that               ways        and means            are     found        to avoid        the kind          of situation
  that     we are           faced       with      today,          because           it jeopardizes              the essence              of Unescols               activities.
  It is not easy                for    us to commit                 ourselves             to any       of the proposals                  mentioned             in this          re-
   gard      unless          the matter             is given          further          consideration.                  1 trust      that     the Executive                   Board
                                                                                            217

further        ways       and means             of rationalization                 of the administrative                   expenses           of the Organi-
zation.          These       possibilities             have       been      dwelt       on in the suggestion                 put forward           by the Soviet
delegation,            with      which       we are         in full      agreement.
20. 5          1 would       like     to underline               nevertheless              that,       when      saying      this,       we are       not inany
way      against        development.                 What       we are         for    is rationalization               directed          towards        greater
stress        on helping           developing           countries            to achieve           their      goals    in the fields            of education,
science         and culture.                My    country,           too,      is   a small           country,         and      one      where        planned
economy           governs          the financial              system.           For     us,     just      as for     SO many          other      countries,          a
 sudden        change       in the budget              would        cause        certain       problems.             In saying          this,     1 would       like
to repeat          our     suggestion,             already          made        several       times,         to the effect          that,      with    further
economization               and rationalization,                      the efficiency             of programme               activities          could     be in-
creased          and administrative                    expenses           reduced.
 20. 6         TO conclude,               1 would        like     to state,         however,            Mr.      President,           that     in our     vote      on
 the draft        resolution            we do not intend                 to hinder         the Organization                in its      attempt       to find       a
 way     out of this          difficult        situation.           Thank        you,     Mr.       President.
