22. 1         Mr.      KANU          (Sierra        Leone):
               Mr.     President,             since        1 indicated           my    intention          to speak       at today’s           plenary       of the
third      session        of the General                Conference,               several        distinguished            delegates           have     already
made        some       of the points             1 wanted          to make         when      1 requested            the microphone.                  1 shall
therefore           not take         much        of the time            of the Conference                  by repeating           points        which     have
 been      made       with      clarity       and vigour            by others.
 22. 2         Mr.      President,             1 wish        to renew          the Sierra           Leone       Government’s               unfailing       dedica-
 tion    to the high           principles           on which           Unesco        was      founded.           We are         aware        of the vital         work
 which       this    Organization               is doing,          especially           in the developing               nations         of the world.              Con-
 sequently,           Mr.       President,            the Government                   of Sierra          Leone      does not,         at this    stage,      favour
 the idea        of reducing            or freezing             the activities             of Unesco,            especially          in the field         of
 education.
 22. 3         As regards             the budgetary                problems           which       this     Conference          was convened            to tackle,
 my     delegation          would        like     to associate             itself      with     those       who have         rightly        pointed      out that
 inflation,         the primary              cause        of the problem,                 was      and is being        exported          from     the developed
 nations        to the developing                  countries           of the world.               My      delegation        shares         the view,        there-
  fore,     that     the developing                countries           cannot       be made          to bear       the burden            of this     problem.
  In making          this     point,        Mr.      President,            I have        at the back           of my     mind       the lucid        and clear
  presentation            by the Director-General                          of the       serious         financial       problems            which      Unescois
                                                                                    220


                                                                                                                                                             3x14
facing        as a result           of inflation        and the devaluation                   of the dollar.             If I heard        him      correctly          -
and here           1 stand       to be corrected              - the Director-General                       remarked,           inter     alia,       that     those
countries           whose        currencies          have      been      revalued         upwards           in relation        to the dollar            may       not
have       to make         supplementary               payments           which       are     needed        to offset       the huge        deficit       in the
current          budget       of Unesco.            The     implication           of this,        Mr.       President,          is that      those       poor
countries           whose        currencies          are     unavoidably            tied     to a weak          international          currencywhich
has been           devalued         Will    have     to pay        more,       while       rich     countries         whose      powerful         economies
make         an upward           revaluation          of their        currencies            inevitable         will    pay less.          Such       a situa-
tion     should        not and must            not be allowed              to persist.
22. 4           Nor     cari we solve           the problem             by simply           changing         the currency            of accounting,
since        every      major         currency        is subject          to the strains            and stresses             of the current             insta-
bility       in the money             markets        of the world.              Today         we are        meeting        to find     solutions           to the
problems            of inflation          and the devaluation                 of the dollar.               A change         to a stronger             currency
might         well    bring       us together          again       to consider         the high        cost of purchasing             the new currency
of accounting.                  My     delegation        therefore          wishes        to recommend                the immediate              introduction
of an Exchange                  Compensation             Allowance           into     the accounting              system,         SO that      the fluctua-
tions       in international              currencies           cari be reflected               in the records             of Unesco          and the actual
 contributions             of the Member               States.         The     aim,       Mr.      President,           is to find        a just       and equi-
 table      system         of contributions             in spite        of the present             chaotic        state     of affairs        in the inter-
national          money         markets.          In other         words,       Member            States       should       not be made            to profit        or
lose      as a result            of the rise        and fa11 in the value                  of major          currencies.
  22. 5          Finally,         Mr.     President,           my delegation              wishes         to stress         mat,     while       the Sierra
  Leone        Government              appreciates           the measures              already          taken     by the Director-General                        to
  reduce         the deficit         in the budget           of Unesco,          it remains           our earnest          hope that these            measures
  will    not reduce            the effectiveness                of Unesco         or lead        to its      stagnation.            Thank          you,
   Mr.      President.

  of account,            by interna1             savings       and with         the Appropriation                  Reserve,           without         recourse           to
  supplementary                 estimates.
  26. 3         Secondly,             my      delegation         wishes       to thank         the Executive              Board        for    having        made
  the excellent             recommendation                   contained          in paragraph               28 of document               3 XC/4.
   26. 4         Mr.       President,             as has      been       SO eloquently             recounted          by the Vice-Chairman                        ofthe
   Executive          Board          in his      report,        and as has           been     pointed         out by a number                 of delegations,
   this     recommendation                    is a result         of an extensive               and      thorough           study       by     the      Executive
   Board.          In the view            of my       delegation,           it enables           our     Organization             to preserve             the vital
   part      of its    programmes                  approved          by the seventeenth                   session       of the General               Conference,
   while      keeping         the amount             of supplementary                  appropriations               to     the      minimum.               Thus        it
   represents            the best          possible        compromise               under       the present           circumstances                 - the most
    realistic        approach           to the solution              of the problem               our      Organization            now faces.
    26. 5        In view         of this,         Mr.     President,           my      delegation           is prepared            to accept          and Support
    the recommendation                        made     by the Executive                 Board.
    26. 6        Having          said     that,      Mr.     President,            1 would         like    to add a few remarks                  on some         points
    relevant        to the Board’s                 recommendation.
    26. 7         My first          remark          concerns          the outstanding                payments         of assessed             contributions.
    I recall       that,      in his       introductory             speech       yesterday,             the Director-            General          stated       that
    one-third         of the total             amount       of the contributions                    for    1973 is outstanding                 at this        very
     moment.           According              to my      calculations,             this     represents,            in terms           of absolute           figures,
                                                                                     224


                                                                                                                                                                  3XCl4
some        18 million           dollars.          NO doubt           it Will        greatly        improve          the tight        cash      position        of the
Organization,               if these        outstanding             contributions               are    promptly           paid.        Therefore,             my
delegation           wishes         to appeal          to the         Member               States      concerned           to make          every       effort      to
expedite         the payment              of those        outstanding                contributions.
26. 8          Mr.      President,            some       observations                 and suggestions                 have     been      made       as to the
desirability            of finding         a solution           to put the Organization’s                         finances         on a more            stable
basis,       a solution            which      Will     insulate         or isolate            the Organization’s                 programmes                 and
budget        from      the effects           of future          fluctuations              of the international                monetary          system.          My
delegation           recognizes            the desirability                 of finding          such      a solution          but,     at the same            time,
my     delegation           feels      that     the financial             and monetary                impacts          and      implications               such       a
solution         may      possibly         have      on the Member                    States       should        be thoroughly               studied          before
the Organization                  takes     any      action        which       Will      introduce          changes         to its      present        financial
and accounting                system.            Also,       since       this       is a problem             common           to other          parts        of    the
United       Nations           system        of organizations,                    such      studies       may       be conducted             in conjunction
with     other       agencies          and organizations.                      In view          of these        considerations              and of the limited
time      available          to this       session        of the General                   Conference,            my      delegation          feels      that    this
extraordinary                session        of the General               Conference              should      concentrate            its efforts        on tackling
the immediate                problem          which       urgently           requires           a solution.
 26. 9          Mr.     President,             from      its     national          point      of view,         my      Government             is not entirely
 satisfied         with     the     Board’s         recommendation,                       and it was          not without           difficulty        that     my
 Government              has      decided         to accept          this     recommendation.                       My Government                  had two        dif-
 ficulties:         one concerns              the schedule              of the payment                 of assessed             contributions,              and the
 other,        the authorization                 of loans.            I Will       not go into          the substantive               details       of the prob-
 lem     but,      with      your      permission,               1 would         like     to touch       on them         very      briefly.
  26. 10        As for        the payment             schedule,            under         the complex             budgetary           and appropriation
  procedures            of my Government,                      it is extremely                  difficult       to make         the payment              of supple-
  mentary          contributions             according             to this        schedule         of payments.                My Government                  bas     al-
  ways      taken       meticulous            tare      to meet          its    international             financial         obligations           in time,         and it
  is not without             some       pain      that    it visualizes               a situation          in which         it Will      have      to carry          ar-
  rears       in the payment               of its      contributions.
  26. 11        With      respect         to the authorization                     of short-term               loans,       my Government                   has al-
  ways      held      the view         that     an international                  organization             should,        as a matter            of principle,
  avoid      contracting             loans,       under       any but really                 exceptional            circumstances.                  My Govern-
  ment’s        attitude        is based          on rather           obvious          reasons.           Namely,           an international                organiza-
  tion    financially            depending          on the assessed                    contributions             of     Member           States         should        -net
   burden       the Member               States       with     the eventual                aàditional         costs      required         for    the payment              of
                                                                                      225


3XCf4
interests.            Another         reason         is that       the rates           of assessment                  applicable            at the time            of au-
thorizing          loans       and those         expected           to be in force               at the time             of the repayment                   of capital
and interests              may      presumably              differ,        thus     possibly            resulting          in an inequitable                  distribu-
tion      of financial          burdens        among          the Member                States.
26. 12          In spite       of these       difficulties,             my Government                     has     decided           to accept          the relevant
parts        of the Executive              Board’s          recommendation,                       firstly        because           my Government                   rea-
lizes       the urgent          necessity          of securing               funds       for     supplementary                     appropriations,                  and

expected.             My Government’s                    decision          was      also      prompted             by the complete                  trust      it places
in the        Director-General,                   that     he Will        exercise            every        caution        to keep          the amount            of loan
he contracts             to a necessary                 minimum.
 26. 13         Mr.     President,           as I said          at the outset,                my Government                    considers             the recommen-

and participation                 in these          programmes                 of development                to be vital       for     our     success.
28. 4          Mr.       President,             my     country          supports          fully     the growth         of Unesco           and urges            a11
Member            States       to support           the resolution                of the Executive               Board      which         we hope         Will     en-
sure      that     the operations                of our       Organization               Will    continue        as envisaged            by the seventeenth
session          of the General                Conference.                Thank        you.

(30. 1) Mr.          GOTOV          (Mongolia)            (Translation              from          the Russian):
       Mr.      President,           permit         me, on behalf                of our delegation,                   to congratulate              you once more                  on
being elected          to occupy           the high office               of President                of the extraordinary                 session         of the General
Conference,           and to assure               you of our conviction                       that your competence                     and experience                Will help us
in this session           to find an effective                   and satisfactory                     solution         to the financial                 problems              of our
Organization.
(30. 2) In the opinion                of our delegation,                    the prestige               and future         of Unesco          willdepend             in large         mea-
sure on the solution                of the difficult              and serious              financial          problem         now facing the third extraordinary
session      of the General              Conference.                 In order          to solve this problem,                      it is essential             first      to identify
a11 the causes           responsible             for the budget               deficit,           and then to find ways of eliminating                               them.          In our
7
opmion,         merely        to recognize             the shortage              of budgetary               funds and take measures                        to overcome               the
crisis     by means           of supplementary                   contributions               alone is insufficient,                  since this does not go to the
root of the evil,             with the result              that,       in a few years I time,                      we shall again be faced with the same
financial       problem         and again have to draw                          up supplementary                      estimates,            thus further              enlarging
Unesco’s         already        swollen         budget.
 (30. 3) As we a11 know very well,                              the fundamental                    reasons        for the deficit           in Unesco’s              budget        are
the devaluation            of the American                  dollar,         the currency                of accounting,             and inflation.              The first           thing
that strikes         us, Mr.          President,             is that,         on account              of these two basic               factors,         for which            only a
few countries            are responsible,                 a11 the other               Member            States      are also having               to suffer.           And the
 Organization          itself     is being impared.                      In the opinion                of our delegation,               this state of affairs                    cannot
last;     measures           must be taken to remedy                           the situation.
(30. 4) We consider                 that the deficit               in Unesco’s              budget        could be covered                in large         measure            from
the interna1         resources            of the Organization                    and in lesser               measure          by supplementary                   contributions
from      Member         States.          In this connexion,                   Mr.       President,             we also think that it would be unjust                                 to
demand        supplementary                contributions              from those countries                       which       are not responsible                   for the causes
 of the deficit,         for this would,                in the last resort,                       be an infringement                  of the principle                 of basing
States’     contributions             on their         national         income.             We continue              to take the view that the rate of in-
 crease     of Unesco            Member             States’        contributions                  should       not exceed           the rate          of growth             of their
 national      incomes.
 (30. 5) As regards               the interna1             resources            referred             to above,         there     is no doubt           that our Organiza-
 tion does possess               such resources.                    By “interna1                resources”               our    delegation            means           unj.ustified
 expenditure,          which       could be used to caver                        the budget deficit.
(30. 6) It is essential                to take measures                    to curtail            such expenditure               severely          and to use the re-
sources       thus saved to help caver                        the budget deficit.                      These       resources           could be obtained,                   in our
opinion,       by temporarily                freezing         vacant         posts and simplifying                      the structure            of the Secretartat,
considerably           curtailing          the recruitment                  of temporary                personnel          and consultants,                 greatly        reducing
the volume          and number             of officia1         documents,                meetings,            conferences,             missions           and SO on.
(30. 7) Another             important           means         of eliminating                the budget deficit                would be to extend                  the right          of
Member         States to pay part of their                        contributions                in their       own national            currencies,             more        especial-
ly those members                 who are not responsible                          for    the devaluation                and inflation          which        are the main
causes      of Unesco’s            present         large       deiicit.
 (30. 8) Such, Mr.               President,             are our delegation’s                       views      on Unesco’s            present        financial          situation
and the measures                that must be taken to remedy                                it.      Our delegation             assures         you that we shall lend
the necessary            support         and co-operation                   for the implementation                        of any constructive                  proposals            to
deal with the problem                   under        discussion            which        the delegates              of other       countries           may put forward.
Thank      you.

31.       Le PRESIDENT                    :
         Je remercie              M.     Gotov.           Je donne          maintenant            la parole        à S. Ext.             M.     Cummings,
chef      de la délégation                du Libéria.
32. 1           Mr.      CUMMINGS                  (Liberia):
                Mr.      President,              the Liberian              delegation          has pleasure              in taking         part    in this       very
serious          and important                debate         affecting         the future          and very        life      of this      Organization.              My
Government                has always              supported            the wisdom            and     discretion          of the Director-General                     and
the members                 of the Executive                  Board,          who    enjoy       our confidence               as a result        of the authority
and responsibility                   granted           them       by our        suffrage.           My delegation                therefore         supports         the
recommendations                     of the Executive                    Board       and the Director-General                          in their       search        for a
solution          to the grave            financial           problems            which      confront        the Organization                  at this       time.
 32. 2          My      delegation           considers            the solutions             put forward           by the Executive                  Board        and
the Director-General                         in respect            of the financial              situation       to be clear,              understandable,
practical,             reasonable             and most           appropriate,              if the issue          must        be resolved           with       speed.
 The      financial         problems             which        confront         the Organization                are     not hypothetical,                theoreti-
 cal    nor      the result         of some            imaginary             phenomena.                The   issues          are    the result         of present-
 day     economic            conditions             which       exist      throughout           the world.            Devaluation            and inflation          are
 realities          and facts         of life.           No one cari deny                this,      because        every          country       is experiencing
 their       effects       in some           shape       or other          form.
  32. 3         Mr.       President,              it is gratifying              to note      that      the Director-General                     and the Execu-
  tive     Board        have     already            engaged          in efforts       to find        a solution            to     the     present         financial
  crisis       by endeavouring                   to discover             savings       within        the programme                  and budget,           which        in
  essence          is not an act of saving                       per      se,    but a curtailing             of some           of the important               activi-
  ties     and programmes                     of the Organization.                     This       kind     of exercise             could      not continue           with-
  out seriously              affecting          the quality            of the work           of Unesco.
  32. 4          Mr.      President,              the rôle         of Unesco,          in the opinion             of my delegation,                is to improve
  the worth           and value          of mankind              and not to reduce                  or destroy           its quality.          When      a man         sets
  out to build           a house,           he does          SO with        a view       of developing             a structure             that    Will    be safe,
  durable,           and lasting.              If for      any      reason        the high         cost    of labour           or materials           alters        or
  changes          the original            estimate,            he never           considers           reducing         the cost         of the building            by
  resorting           to cheaper            labour         and inferior            materials,            which      would         pose       a threat           to   its
  durability;           rather,        he seeks             to supplement             these        additional         costs        by practical          means,
  such      as loans         or extra           contributions               and SO forth.               The    same         seems        to be applicable              to
  our     present         situation.              It is therefore              obvious          that,     if we continue               to find     a solution           to
  our     present         financial          problems            by reducing            the quality          of work           of our      Organization             and
  also      by curtailing            its     programmes                  and activities,             it is the developing                  countries          which
                                                                                     230


Will be most           adversely          affected;        and thus         the very         concept          of improving             the worth         of the
individual          through       education,            science,          and culture,             which        is the principal             objective            of
Unesco,           would     have      been      lost.
 32. 5         It would       be most         unfortunate,             Mr.        President,            if in the final           analysis       this     Organi-
zation        should      attempt         to measure             the worth          and dignity             of man       and the preservation                      of
peace        in terms        of dollars          and cents.             It is true        that    $12,       652, 100 is a considerable                    amount
in terms           of financial        outlay,         but in terms              of the application                of this       amount        and the objec-
tives      it is destined           to achieve,            this     is nominal.              My delegation                therefore        appeals          to the
conscience            of a11 our        colleagues            here      present,          to exercise             wisdom         and sound          judgement
in disposing            of this      very      serious         yet vital         issue.        We realize             that    the contribution                of the
 more        developed         nations        would       be enormous,                 at this      critical        period        in the economies                  of
 a11 countries,             but   comparatively                speaking           the burden           Will     be equally           enormous           for       the
  developing           countries,           which       are     faced      with      even      greater         financial         strain     in their         develop-
  ment      process.
   32. 6        It is for      the foregoing             and other           reasons         that     the Liberian             delegation         supports
  the proposals            and recommendations                        of the Director-General                         and the Executive                Board,
  as contained           in documents               3 XC/3         and 3 XC/4,              which        clearly        outline       the present           finan-
  cial    position       of the Organization                   and propose              the most           practical         approach         to a solution
  of the      same.         Thank      you Mr.           President.

  34. 1         Mr.     MUKA        (Kenya):
                Mr.     President,           first     1 want       to congratulate               you for         being       elected        to    this       high
 office       of Presidency            of this       third      extraordinary               session          of the General              Conference.                You
 have      performed           your      duty      with     unparalleled             wisdom.              Your     guidance          has    certainly           con-
 tributed         to the progress              we have         made        SO far.
  34. 2         Next    1 wish       to express            my     sincere         gratitude         to the Vice-Chairman                      of the Execu-
  tive   Board        and to the Director-General                            for    the clear,            precise        and scholarly            wayinwhich
  they    introduced          the topic         under        discussion,             namely,           supplementary                  estimates.             From
  document           3 XC/4       we are         able     to read        the financial            situation         of the Organization,                    andthe
  measures           the Secretariat               has    SO far       exercised           in an attempt              to tope        with    the crisis             or
  part    of the.crisis.              This      document           provides           a written          addition        to the oral         exposition             by
  the Chairman             of the Executive                Board        and the Director-General                            which      we had yesterday.
   The    deficit      outlined,        that      is U. S. $12,            625, 100,         is not a small               sum      that cari be contained
  within       normal       measures.               As we have             seen,       the Secretariat               tried      to deal        with       it,       but
   sooner       or later,        were       forced       to ask       for     help.       There       is a saying          in my      vernacular,             literally
                                                                                   231


 3XCl4
translated,            which        says”he        who      coughs          is better         than       he who          scratches           himself”.             The
 Director-General,                     as head        of the Secretariat,                    has     coughed,             the Executive              Board,          elec-
ted by us,            the General             Assembly,              have       heard      his     cough       and reacted               positively,             as we see
in document              3 XC/4.            We are         now here             responding           to the original                 cough       from       the
 Director-          General.
 34. 3         It iS gratifying              to look       around         and see that             the turnout              for     this      session         is    very
large       despite        the short          notice.         This        confirms           the co-operative                   spirit      we Member               States
of LJnesco           have.         It also      indicates           the faith        we have           in our        Organization.                 It is todaythat
1 realize          that    Unesco          is us and we are                  Unesco.           It is today             that     1 have      known        that      we are
united       in our        course.           Rich      and poor,            developing            and developed,                   third        world,          second
and first          world,         we are        a11 convened             here       as equal         Member              States        of Unesco,              seeking
a solution           to enable          Unesco         to move         ahead         once      again.
34. 4          Yesterday             1 listened         to fourteen             speeches.            1 have         listened          to another          sixteen        to-
day.        Al1 these           speeches         are      precise,           to the point           and enlightening;                   indeed        heartening.
We may           vary      in clarity,           we may          vary       in approach,              we may            vary      in emphasis              and where
we put that            emphasis.               But    the concluding                remarks           from         nearly          a11 the          distinguished
 delegates           who have           spoken       have      indicated            a positive           stand       - a stand          in favour           of supple-
mentary           estimates.               For    this     1 wish       to thank          those      who        have         already            spoken         and      ex-
pressed          their      Government’s                 wish      to support            the      supplementary                     appropriation.                  My
 earnest         appeal        to a11 of us delegates                    is that       we cast          our    vote        and cast         it in favour            ofthe
 required           sum.         Namely         U. S.      $12,      625,100.            A unanimous                  vote     would       indeed        be ideal         as
 it would         reflect        our     committed           and sympathetic                   attitude        to the uncomfortable                        situation
 that    our     Organization               has    found      itself       in,     an uncomfortable                     situation         that     has been          im-
 posed       by external             circumstances                beyond          the control            of Unesco.
  34. 5         My     country,           Kenya,         belongs        to the developing                    world.          As members                of the       devel-
  oping      world       we see Unesco                 in terms           of the programmes                      it carries            out in our           countries
 or     assists         us    in     achieving.             1 know         right      now we cannot                   mount          certain         programmes
  that   we were           to have         implemented               with       Unesco’s         assistance,               the reason           being     that Unesco
  has just        not got the funds,                 which        is an indication                that      the programme                   as approved              by the
 General          Conference              at its    seventeenth               session        in November                  1972      is suffering.                There       -
  fore    ifwe      approve          the supplementary                     estimates            in    their        entirety,            Kenya         Will       benefit
  from      Unesco          and become             more       literate.             And     it is not only                Kenya         which        Will       benefit;
  but a11 the Member                     States      of Unesco.                This    in itself          is a        satisfaction             both      to      Unesco
  and to the Member                     States.
   34. 6        A few        suggestions            have      been       made        by some            delegates.               These         suggestions             are
   said    to be suitable              to shield         Unesco         from        getting       itself      into       a serious          financial          situation
  again.         These        are      good     suggestions             and have           merit        in them.             But      my feeling           is that      we
                                                                                     232


                                                                                                                                                                     3XCl4
should         leave       these        suggestions              for    the eighteenth              session           of    the General              Conference

wants         to vote        for     the resolution;               and my Government                      has instructed               me to vote            on its be-
half      for    the resolution.                 In the spirit             of Harambee,               1 look       forward        to seeing        a11 of us unani-
mously           approving            the required               supplementary                estimates           of U. S. $12,625,100.                        A cough-
ing man            is given        medicine            for     relief      and we should               give     it.      Thank        you Mr.          President.

36.1         M.      REZA         (Iran)       :
          Monsieur             le Président,               la délégation             de l’Iran,          soucieuse            de respecter             l’unanimité
 qui     s’est       faite      au Conseil            exécutif         à propos          de l’ouverture               de crédits           supplémentaires,
 unanimité            que nous            espérons           retrouver           à la Conférence                 générale,          votera        en faveur           des
 propositions               présentées            par      le Conseil.            Cette       approbation             ne nous         dispense           cependant
 pas     d’exprimer              notre        opinion         sur     certains         points      qui,     à notre         avis,       sont     d’une       extreme
 importance               pour      l’avenir        de l’Organisation.
  36.2         En effet,         Monsieur            le Président,               c’est       avec      un très        vif    regret        que nous          assistons
  à la mutilation                du programme                   approuvé          par     la Conférence                générale         lors     de sa dix-sep-
  tième        session.          Nous         avons       de fortes          raisons         de croire          que l’inflation              et la dévaluation
  de la monnaie                 de compte           de l’Organisation,                    lesquelles           résultent         toutes        deux      du désordre
  monétaire             international             qui a perturbé               les     finances         de l’Organisation,                    sont    très      loin
  d’avoir         les     memes           effets      sur     l’économie            de tous        les    Etats        membres.             S’il   est      vrai      que
  cette      perturbation               a lesé      certains           Etats,       il n’en       reste      pas moins             qu’elle       en a pour          ainsi
  dire      favorisé          un plus         grand       nombre           encore.         On nous         répondra           peut-etre,            et cela        a été
   dit au cours             des discussions                  du Conseil           exécutif,          que    “l’essentiel”              du programme                  sera.
   executé          ; mais       cette       notion       “d’essentiel”             n’a     rien     de rassurant              pour      l’avenir.            On     a
  bloqué         un nombre             important            de postes           vacants,          on a supprimé                des réunions,               on a sus-
  pendu         des publications.                 Dira-t-on              que tout       cela     ne fait       pas partie           de l’essentiel              ? Etant
   donné       qu’il      n’y    avait       pas    de double             emploi       entre      les    fonctions           des membres                du Secréta-
   riat,      qu’une        conférence             des représentants                    d’Etats       ne peut         remplacer             un petit       colloque
   sur     une question               spécialisée,              qu’aucune          publication           de 1’Unesco             ne nous         dispense          de la
   lecture         d’une       autre,        que l’exécution                d’une      partie       du programme                 de 1’Unesco              est    “de
   circonstance”                et ne saurait              être      ajournée         sans      perdre        son i.ntérét           ; étant      donné        enfin
   que le taux            d’augmentation                 du programme                  approuvé          par      la Conférence               générale,            soit
    5, 66 %, se trouve                   réduit      à 0, 84 %, ce qui                est le taux         le plus         faible      que l’organisation
                                                                                      233


 3XCl4
 ait    jamais          connu,         nous        sommes          persuadés                que l’organisation                 subit       ainsi      des pertes
considérables.
 36. 3 Je répète,                Monsieur             le Président,                que,        soucieux           de préserver             l’unanimité,            nous
acceptons           toutes      les      coupures            proposées             dans le programme,                     mais        la perspective             d’un
avenir       où ce précédent                  créerait          une tradition                “d’économie”               nous     inquiète         infiniment.
 36.4       Etant       donné       que l’inflation              est un processus                      ordinaire         dans      l’évolution           de l’écono-
mie mondiale               et que la conjoncture                  internationale                 ne laisse         pas entrevoir            de perspectives             très
 claires       en ce qui          concerne            le désordre             monétaire,                 il faut que,        sur     la proposition             du Di-
 recteur       général,         le Conseil            exécutif,         puis la Conférence                      générale       à sa dix-huitième                session,
 examinent            d’une     manière            approfondie             ce problème                  ; et si une solution                définitive       ne pouvait
 pas      être     trouvée         dans       un proche           avenir,            il     devrait         être      possible         d’augmenter            la réserve
  budgétaire,             de façon         à créer           une marge              appréciable               de souplesse             qui permettrait              d’évi-
  ter,     à chaque          période         budgétaire,              une amputation                    du programme                 ou la convocation               d’une
   session       extraordinaire                 de la Conférence                    générale.
   36. 5 Je vous             remercie,              Monsieur           le Président.

4.1             Mr.     SEDDOH              (Ghana):
                Mr.       President,             as Ghana          has fully        participated               in the examination                   of the         propos-
als placed            before        us,      1 shall      refrain        from      going        into     much        detail       in my remarks                   on the
item      under        discussion.               This      has already            been        ably     done       by the Vice-Chairman                          of the
Executive             Board       in his presentation                   and supported                by the Director-General.                              The      pro-
posals        for     which       the approval              of the General               Conference              is being          sought       were        largely
due to the consensus                       among        members             of the Executive                 Board.             This    was      brought           about
by the spirit              of compromise                 in view        of the grave              financial         difficulties          which         face        our
Organization.                   This     crisis,         as the Director-General                          told     us yesterday,               is the first             of
its   kind       in the history               of Unesco          and, having           listened          carefully          to the statements                  of those
who      have       preceded           me,      1 am happy             to say      that      the spirit          of compromise                  noticed          during
the deliberations                  of the Board              appears         to have         caught         on also        in this       Bxtraordinary                 Con-
 ference.            The      indications           therefore           are    that     our      discussions              will     lead    to a successful
 conclusion.
 4.2            Mr.      President,             we have         met      to find      a solution            to the financial              crisis        whichplagues
 our    Organization.                  The      situation         is an extraordinary                     one and therefore                   calls       for     extraor-
dinary         measures.               If 1 may         borrow         a local      expression,                 we are         assembled           here        to apply
 what     amounts            to “traitement               à chaud”          to the crisis             facing        Unesco,           brought        about        by the
 combined            effects       of inflation           and the devaluation                    of the dollar.                Obviously,            if this        shock
 treatment            or,     if you      like,      this     form       of therapy           is to have           any meaningful                and lasting              re-
 sults,       it follows          that     the efforts          being       deployed           by us to find             a solution          to the crisis              should
 not end here.                 It is therefore              gratifying         to note         that     this     concern           of ours       has been            taken
 up by the Director-General                             during       his     exposé        in which           he outlined            the long-term                plans       of
 the Organization                  aimed        at checking            a recurrence                 of the present               unsatisfactory               situation.
  4.3           Mr.       President,            we are         being       asked      to approve             supplementary                 estimates             totalling
  $14,    252, 100.            After      certainadjustments,                    this      figure        has been          brought        down to _-~---  $12, 652, 100
  which        must        be recovered               from       Member           States         in the form              of assessed              contributions.
  This     supplementary                  appropriation              represents,               we are        told,       just     a small        percentage              of the
  approved           total      budget        and should           not be unbearable.                      Truc,        if we think           of the vast             sums
  of money           being       swallowed            up in the arms              race        in a world            which        has set up Unesco                    to con-
  struct       the defences              of peace         in men’s          minds,       the supplementary                       estimates          now being              dis-
  cussed        would        appear         to be a drop            of water         in the ocean.                 But     cari we really              and honestly
  say    this      for    the fragile           economies            of developing               countries?
  4. 4           In my statement                to the seventeenth                 session          of the General                Conference             last     year,      1
  made      it clear        that     countries          of the Third            World         were      not in a position              to increase            their        pre-
  sent    level        of contribution.              1 further        appealed          to those          Member            States      which      were        in a position
  to c0ntribut.e             more       to do SO and not limit                  their       efforts        in the promotion                 of real         happiness            for
                                                                                    241


  3XCf5
millions            of people         through        the worthy           cause       of international                 development               assistance.
4. 5             Although          we were          a party       to the consensus                  reached          in the Executive                 Board,          this
was       not without             some       reservation           on our        part.       It is no secret                 that    further         degradation
in the capacity                 of developing             countries         to pay       up as a result                 of fresh        assessed            contribu-
tions,       would        only     perpetuate           the ever-widening                 gulf      between         the industrialized                   and devel-
 oping       countries,             a situation          which      constitutes           a challenge             to social          justice        and a threat
to world            peace.          Mr.     President,           poverty         and affluence               cannot        coexist        indefinitely.                The
question            of seeking           the approval           of supplementary                    estimates            in our       countries            is     not    as
easy        as we are            given      to understand.                The     present         financial          crisis       facing        Unesco,           we are
told,       is foreign            to the Organization.                   It is equally             SO with        developing             countries,            and 1 am
in entire            agreement            with     my     colleague         from       India       that     it is “inequitable                 to pass          on to
other        countries            the financial           burden       for    which        they      are      not responsible”.
4. 6            We do fully             understand           the argument              that     the imbalance                 in the Unesco               finances
is directly             the result          of world         monetary          instability.              For     the devaluation                 of the US dollar
and the revaluation                      of the West           German         mark        and a couple               of other         major        currencies
are      indeed         important           contributory            factors        in the inflationary                   pressures            listed        as     the
second           cause       of imbalance             in the Unesco              accounts.
4. 7             It is clear,         therefore,         that the Member                 States       of Unesco             are    very       much        interested
to see an early                  end to the work               of the Groups             of 20 and 24 currently                        looking         into      the re-
form         of world          monetary           arrangements.                 Until      that      solution         is found,          1 am sure            that     the
 cal1 to poor              countries          to provide         supplementary                votes        for    the operations                 of international
 organizations                Will     continue,         and probably             Will     become           more        frequent.
4. 8             While       the International                Monetary          Fund       is seeking            solutions          which,         hopefully,           Will
give       long-term             relief,        we the Member               States       of Unesco             must       necessarily              seek       ways       of
reducing             the unfavourable                impact        of world         monetary            instability.
4. 9             Two       relevant        proposals           have     been      put forward             by some             other      delegations.                 We
have        been       asked       to adopt        a more        stable       currency           in which          the     budget         of Unesco            will,be
 expressed.                 The main           reason       for    such     an arrangement                    is that       over      70 per        cent      of the
 expenditure               of Unesco           is in French           Francs.            For      such       an arrangement                  to prove           bene-
 ficial,        two      conditions          must      be fulfilled.            Firstly,          the French              Franc       must        remain          quite
 stable        SO that,        for    most       Member          States,      their      own       domestic            currency           equivalent             of con-
 tributions            assessed           on them        Will    not vary.
 4. 10           Secondly,           domestic          inflation       in France            must       not get out of hand,                     SO that        the real
value         of contributions                paid    Will     be maintained              to a reasonable                  degree.
 4.11             It has been           proposed          that    a more         stable      currency            should         be adopted            for     the cur-
 rency         of accounting.                In our       view,      this    latter       proposa1            coincides          with      the proposa1               for
 the adoption               of the Franch             Franc       for    budgetary           purposes,              subject        to the following                 stipu-
                                                                                    242


                                                                                                                                                                     3xw5
  lation:         that     a special           unit    of account            be adopted          with      an established                parity        relationship
 to the currency                  of every         Member           State.        Suppose,          for     example,            that     we were            to cal1
  such     a unit       of accounting               the --Unec,        it would        mean       that     a parity         between           the --  Unec      and
 the currency               of every         Member            State      would       be established,               and in this             way,       instability
 in a world            reserve          currency          would        not affect         the operations               of Unesco.               Of course,           such
 an arrangement                   would       not insulate            the operations              of Unesco            against         price       inflationin           the
 main       markets           where        Unesco         makes         purchases.              However,           price         inflation         per     se is easier
 to dealwith,             since       a reasonable             forecast          cari be made              and the shortfall                   or otherwise              on
a forecast            is not likely            to be large,             and in many             cases       could       be accommodated                      within       the
 same        budget.           What       is disturbing             is the effect           of devaluation               which,         sometimes,              doesnot
even       reflect        relative         efficiency          and inefficiency               in the domestic                 economies.                 In recent
times,          it is not unusual                to find      the currency              of the high-cost                country          appreciating              against
the currency                of the low-cost               country.            In any case,            when      devaluation              does       occur        in    the
principal           currency,            it usually         triggers           off devaluation             and even           revaluation             of a few other
currencies.
4.12            Our      two main          proposals            on these         issues       therefore          are:        (i)     from        the pointof           view
of countries              whose         currencies           are     not directly           exchangeable                into      French          Francs,          the
adoption           of the French              Franc        as the        budget        currency         Will     still     not insulate              them      from
the effects            of the instability               of the US dollar                or of the Pound                sterling.             This     is because
many        of these          countries           hold    their      currency           reserves          in US dollars                or the Pound sterling
and therefore                changes         in parity          between         the French            Franc       and these             two      or other        reserve
currencies              Will     affect     them       then      as now.           Thus,        even     as a short-term                    solution,          assess-
ing     contributions               in French          Francs          Will     only     help    the     Member            States        whose        reserves           are
held      in French            Francs.            It is therefore              important          to seek        a neutral            unit     of account            such
as the suggested                   Unec,whichwould                    be insulated            from      the direct            effects         of currency             de-
valuation.
4.13           In addition             to this        measure,            we also        wish      to propose            consideration                of the       IMF
type      of quota         subscription,              which      allows        part     of a member’s                contribution               to be made             in
the domestic                currency          of the member.                    This     Will    reduce        considerably                 the foreign            ex-
change         burden         of Unesco            membership               for    developing           countries.              Under         such       an arrange-
ment,        if,     say,      it is planned            to spend          $200,      000 in Ghana,              and the annual                  contribution            of
Ghana        in the particular                  year     is assessed              at ($300,000,            then      Ghana         would         be called         upon
to pay       in dollars            or French           Francs,           etc.,      only     the difference                of $100,          000      whilst        the
remaining             g200,OOO            would       be credited            to the account             of Unesco            in Ghana,             probably          in
the books            of the Central               Bank.
 4.14            Mr.      President,            we in Ghana              are     really      urging        Unesco         to seek          as a matter             of ur-
 gency       a viable          financial         arrangement               which       allons       least     instability            in project           implemen-
                                                                                    243


tation       and makes             the minimum                 adverse         impact          on the economies                 of the developing
members.
4.15            The     Director-General                    has had to absorb                    as much          as $7, 847, 900 resulting                   from
inflation         over      which        he had no control,                    without         touching         the integrity         of the programme.
He and his             staff     should        be congratulated                  for    their        efforts.
4.16           We are         equally         impressed             by the austerity                  measures           envisaged         by the Director-
 General.            But we still           believe        that it would           not be asking              too much        if the Director-General
were        requested          to take         yet another            look     at his Grganization,                   especially       the administrative
sector.           Any     further          savings         realized         need      not be to the detriment                      of the programme.
 They       may      not necessarily                affect       the effectiveness                    of the programme,                for    when       we talk
about        Growth        it should           not only         be in terms            of quantity            but also       in terms        of quality.
4.17            Mr.      President,              we do support               the recent            innovation          of country        programming
under        which       some         of the operations                 of Unesco            are      mapped         out and executed              directly
within        the Member               States.          In many          cases       this      is a way         to make        such    projects         effective
 as Member              States        may       then     adopt       them       as their          own projects            and therefore             wish    to see
 them       fully     implemented.                       1 may          add       that    it is quite           common         to be sceptical            about
 foreign        consultants,              since       invariably           they      have       to depend          heavily       on the knowledge               of
 local      officiais.           Unesco          Will     have      to tut       out some            of the comings             and goings          of its     staff
 round       the world.              1 am not sure               half     of such          trips       are    necessary.
 4. 18          We are        therefore            particularly             happy       that       the Director-General                   in his     address
 indicated          that     serious          attention         was      being      given        to this,        and that       staff   travel       has already
 been      considerably               reduced.            We would             urge      him       to persist         in the exercise.
  4.19          Al1 told,         in the light           of Ghana’s            unflinching             support        for    Unesco,        we would         vote
  for    the draft         resolution.
  4.20          Finally,         we would           like      to express            our     appreciation             once     again     to the Director-
  General.        and the Executive                   Board        for     the work           they      have     done;and        we hope       and pray         for the
  quick      recovery           of the latter’s              energetic           and enthusiastic                 Chairman,           Dr.      Faad      Sarrfif.
   Thank       you,      Mr.      President.
